Moreover, in this matter, there are not only quantitative aspects to bear in mind, relating to the amount of funding, which has been delayed in fulfilling its commitments, but also qualitative aspects, which are no less important. Among other aspects, due to its responsibility to set an example, it is once again important to denounce the way in which the Commission has sought to impose free trade agreements (so-called economic partnership agreements) on developing countries, despite much resistance. These agreements are becoming a condition, whether explicitly or implicitly, of present and future aid, in an unacceptable act of blackmail.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: The conciliation process saw Parliament back down against the Council’s positions. The report is critical of the Council’s position but it accepts it, in the interests of compromise, on the condition that this does not set a precedent for the future. We are not making light of this discussion on delegated acts, which has been dragging on since discussions on this report began. However, there is more at stake in the discussion on the financing instrument for development cooperation than this issue.

In concrete terms, as the financing instruments are inseparable from the political objectives that they serve, further reflection is needed on one fundamental issue: the direction taken by the EU’s development aid and cooperation policy. Moreover, in this matter there are not only quantitative aspects to bear in mind, relating to the amount of funding, which has been delayed in fulfilling its commitments, but also qualitative aspects, which are no less important. Among other aspects, due to its responsibility to set an example, it is once again important to denounce the way in which the Commission has sought to impose free trade agreements (so-called economic partnership agreements) on developing countries, despite much resistance. These agreements are becoming a condition, whether explicitly or implicitly, of present and future aid.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: Following the second-reading vote of 3 February, and given the political will to conclude the conciliation process as soon as possible, the constituent meeting of the European Parliament (EP) delegation to the Conciliation Committee took place in Strasbourg on 15 February 2011. The EP delegation decided to negotiate the four files concerned – the development cooperation instrument (DCI), the DCI/banana accompanying measures (DCI/BAM), the financing instrument for cooperation with industrialised and other high-income countries (ICI+) and the European Instrument for Democracy & Human Rights (EIDHR) – as a package. On the mid-term review of the DCI and the EIDHR, it was agreed that these instruments would remain unchanged, as no new strategy papers are foreseen until 2013. The EP declares itself ready, in a spirit of compromise, to accept the compromise package, as the remaining duration of the current instruments is rather short. Parliament regrets that it was not possible to further improve the text on the DCI/BAM instrument, particularly in relation to the EP’s role in strategic decisions where an equal footing between the colegislators is essential. In line with the criteria defined in Article 290 paragraph 1, the EP will insist on the use of delegated acts wherever strategic political decisions are involved on financing and programming with regard to those instruments.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcomed this document because the European Parliament has declared that it is ready to accept the compromise package, in a spirit of compromise, as the remaining duration of the current instruments is rather short. It is regrettable that it was not possible to further improve the text of the DCI/BAM (development cooperation instrument/banana accompanying measures) instrument, in particular, in relation to the European Parliament’s role in adopting strategic decisions, where an equal footing between the colegislators is essential. This result should not set a precedent for the future negotiations on the post-2013 external financing instruments. In accordance with the criteria defined in Article 290(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should insist on the use of delegated acts wherever strategic political decisions need to be adopted on the financing and programming of those instruments. It should be noted that the delegation recommended maintaining the package approach and that the Parliament should approve the joint text at third reading.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Even though I do not entirely support the outcome of conciliation on the development cooperation instrument, I voted to support it.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I completely agree with the rapporteur on the bemusement over the lack of equality between institutions in key decisions on this issue. I do, however, think that the proposed compromise should be accepted. My vote is in favour.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: The European institutions have been working on the amendments to this regulation in order to clarify the prohibition on using funding to pay taxes, having decided that EU aid cannot be used to pay taxes, duties or other charges by the recipient countries. I therefore agree with this report, in view of the need to standardise and clarify the aid that is allocated, in order to avoid the misuse of aid granted by the EU.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The financing instrument for development cooperation has a budget of around EUR 17 billion for the period 2007-2013. It aims to eradicate poverty and promote democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. This is an extremely important issue, as it relates to the fight against poverty. At the G20 meeting in Cannes, the Heads of State or Government reiterated the crucial role of official development assistance in achieving the Millennium Development Goals. I sincerely hope that this commitment is honoured in practice. Moreover, at an institutional level, this issue is strategically important. A global compromise has been accepted in a spirit of conciliation because it was essential to find a solution quickly. In future, however, it is vital for the colegislators to be placed on an equal footing.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcome this resolution because the remaining duration of the current instruments is rather short and we therefore need to reach a compromise to ensure the efficiency of external assistance. It is very important to also take into account Parliament’s role in adopting strategic decisions in future. All legislators must be on an equal footing. Moreover, in the future negotiations on the post-2013 external financing instruments, delegated acts should be used when adopting decisions on the financing and programming of those instruments.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I agree with the report on financing for development cooperation because, under the circumstances we find ourselves in, cooperation needs to be given the utmost support available. Cooperation has always been one of the cornerstones of the EU’s work, yet we must learn from the past in order to avoid repeating the mistakes that were made. As I said, we need to make sure that the aid is not scattered around indiscriminately but targeted to where it is actually needed. Parliament had more ambitious goals in mind, but accepts this compromise in order to gain equality with the colegislators so that our work may be faster and more fruitful, and to ensure that the perennial goal of development continues to be among the prerogatives of our governments and unions.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Under the same circumstances as the previous process, A7-0404/2011 , Parliament negotiated to obtain great powers of scrutiny. Conciliation resulted in a joint declaration of the European Parliament and the Council on the future use of delegated acts in the area of external relations for future financial instruments, which strengthens Parliament’s negotiating position vis-à-vis the inclusion of delegated acts in the new instruments. This agreement is crucial to the democratic nature of these financing processes.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: Regulation (EC) No 1905/2006 established a financing instrument for development cooperation, and has recently been subject to a review procedure. However, given the disagreements that arose between the institutions during the legislative process, a conciliation committee was formed. This made it possible, after eight trialogues, to reach a final agreement, confirmed in writing on 24 and 26 October 2011.
I therefore voted in favour, but would emphasise the need for Parliament to be considered as a colegislator in these decision-making processes.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The European Parliament declares it is ready to accept the compromise package in a spirit of compromise as the remaining duration of the current instruments is rather short. It regrets that it was not possible to further improve the text on the DCI/BAM instrument, in particular, in relation to Parliament’s role in strategic decisions where an equal footing between the colegislators is essential. The Parliament underlines that this result does not set a precedent for the future negotiations on the post-2013 external financing instruments. In line with the criteria defined in Article 290, paragraph 1, the European Parliament will insist on the use of delegated acts wherever strategic political decisions are involved on financing and programming with regard to those instruments. The delegation recommends maintaining the package approach, and that the Parliament approves the joint text at third reading.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union establishes the way in which the ordinary legislative procedure for the adoption of an act should function, whereby the Commission presents a proposal to Parliament and the Council. The European institutions have been working on the amendments to the regulation in order to clarify the prohibition on using funding to pay taxes, having decided that EU aid cannot be used to pay taxes, duties or other charges by the recipient countries.
I am voting for this report as I believe that it is necessary to standardise and clarify the aid that is allocated, in order to avoid misinterpretations with regard to aid granted by the EU.

intervention.name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: I abstained on this report, which redefines the regulation on the use of financing instruments for development cooperation. I am generally opposed to paying out these funds, which are often used as a weapon in our relationships with developing countries and their citizens. Moreover, this report makes little progress with regard to the European Parliament’s role in defining the objectives which will underpin the use of the resources thus mobilised. However, I voted in favour of two other reports, which give a more precise idea of how these funds will be used: the report by Kinga Gál and Barbara Lochbihler, which focuses on promoting democracy and human rights, and the one by my colleague and friend, Helmut Scholz, which deals with cooperation with industrialised countries. With these two reports, the European Parliament has gained a more substantial right of scrutiny. This democratic progress is, in itself, positive. It must be used to refocus these instruments on cooperation that is genuinely based on the values of democracy, solidarity and respect for differences, particularly cultural differences.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report at first reading, after amendments relating to conditions for the delegation of powers to the Commission have been introduced by the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament.

intervention.name: Sergio BERLATO
intervention.p: This report looks at the Commission’s proposal on the recast of the regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road. The proposed recast contains a dual goal of the Commission: to codify various acts applicable to road statistics and to set new conditions for the delegation of powers by the legislature to the Commission. In my opinion, the Commission’s request for the delegation of powers set out in the second proposal is too broad, even though it is in line with Article 290 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. At the same time, I believe that it is necessary to ensure that the application of delegated powers would not cause any additional substantial financial burden on statistical respondents. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that it would be best to limit the scope of the powers delegated to the Commission and to set further conditions on exercising them.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: The Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has concluded, in its opinion, that the proposal in question does not include any substantive amendments, and that it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts, without any change in their substance. I therefore voted in favour, as I believe that the proposed amendments form a basis for further negotiations with the Council and the Commission.

intervention.name: David CASA
intervention.p: This proposal was put forward by the Commission in order to recast a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road. I agree with the rapporteur that the Commission's proposals in the recast regulation are much too general and that we must ensure that the amendments would not place any additional financial burdens on statistical respondents. I therefore voted against the Commission’s proposals as I do not think these criteria were met and I would like to engage in further negotiations with the Commission on this particular issue.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road as I believe that the agreement reached by the Council at first reading is positive, particularly with regard to the scope and delegation of powers, as well as the Commission’s obligation to submit a report on the application of the regulation in 2014.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This proposal aims to make the collection of data by type of goods obligatory for road transport statistics and to standardise the type of information collated and processed in the 27 Member States. Being aware of the importance of safe and effective transportation of goods in international trade, I support the Commission’s proposal.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: The objectivity of statistics as a branch of applied mathematics gives it a special status both in the area of scientific research and in public and private organisations. There is no government that does not have a body responsible for statistical studies. The EU itself has the Statistical Office of the European Communities (Eurostat). In an ever-growing area where roads are taking on a key role in the transport of goods, reliable data are vital in order to shape all of the studies in this area, which are only possible using statistics. This report, drafted by Mr Simpson, concerns the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road in the EU (recast). Given the opinion of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, according to which this proposal does not include any substantive amendments, I am voting in favour.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: In its proposal to recast the regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road, the Commission is seeking to extend its delegated powers. The rapporteur rightly believes that the scope of the proposed delegation of powers is too broad. He therefore proposes that this scope be limited, while at the same time ensuring that the financial burden imposed on statistical respondents and the Member States is also limited. This regulation ensures that EU rules are clear and readily understandable, in particular, with respect to statistical data on vehicles, routes and goods.

Member States shall transmit to Eurostat every quarter duly verified individual data corresponding to the aforementioned variables. The proposed approach is identical to the one that has been followed in relation to statistical information on tourism, which has recently been adopted, and which we believe to be appropriate. The usefulness of having reliable statistics which help in drawing up sectoral public policies is thus compatible with not overburdening respondents.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: In its proposal to recast the regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road, the Commission is seeking to extend its delegated powers. The rapporteur rightly believes that the scope of the proposed delegation of powers is too broad. He therefore proposes that this scope be limited, while at the same time ensuring that the financial burden imposed on statistical respondents and the Member States is also limited.

This regulation ensures that EU rules are clear and readily understandable, in particular with respect to statistical data on vehicles, routes and goods. Member States shall transmit to Eurostat every quarter duly verified individual data corresponding to the aforementioned variables. The proposed approach is identical to the one that has been followed in relation to statistical information on tourism, which has recently been adopted, and which we believe to be appropriate. The usefulness of having reliable statistics which help in drawing up sectoral public policies is thus compatible with not overburdening respondents.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: Council Regulation (EC) No 1172/98 of 25 May 1998 on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road has repeatedly been amended in a fundamental way. On the occasion of further amendments, it would be appropriate, on grounds of transparency, to recast this directive. In the interests of fulfilling the roles published by the Commission in connection with the common transport policy, it is appropriate for the Commission to have available comparable, reliable, harmonised, regular and comprehensive statistical data on the scope and development of the carriage of goods by road performed by vehicles registered in the Union, and on the level of use of the vehicles providing this transport. It is necessary to compile comprehensive regional statistics on the carriage of goods and the journeys of vehicles. At the same time, however, the scope of the powers delegated to the Commission should not be too wide. For this reason, and in accordance with the similar procedure adopted in the case of the regulation on statistics in the area of tourism, it would be appropriate, in my opinion, to adopt amendments aimed at restricting the scope of the power delegated to the Commission, and to establish other conditions for the exercise of these powers.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: The Commission proposed this recast for a regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road with the aim, firstly, of codifying various acts applicable to road statistics, and secondly, of setting new conditions for the delegation of powers by the legislator to the Commission. This latter objective is in line with Article 290 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I welcomed these proposals, but I also agree with the rapporteur’s opinion that we must ensure that the application of delegated powers does not cause any additional substantial financial burden for statistical respondents.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The Commission has proposed that the regulation on the carriage of goods by road be recast. The objective is to codify various acts applicable to road statistics and to set new conditions for the delegation of powers by the legislator to the Commission. I supported this report.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted to support Mr Simpson's proposals on this subject.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: The recasting of the regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road was necessary in order to codify a range of acts applicable to road transport statistics and, at the same time, to set new criteria for the delegation of powers. The standardisation of statistical data is essential in order to clearly assess the different data provided by the Member States.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: This report approves the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road. This report does not entail any fundamental change to the subject in question. It is simply a recasting of existing texts, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: In my opinion, the Commission’s proposal for a recast version of a regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road fails to make it clear whether the new conditions for the delegation of powers by the legislators to the Commission entails a further gradual erosion of the subsidiarity principle. The scope of the delegation of powers to the Commission in the proposed new version is too broad. I agree with the rapporteur on this point. However, it is not enough to demand that the exercising of the delegated powers should not place any additional financial burden on those obliged to furnish reports. Instead, in line with the reduction of bureaucracy promised for many years, any new version or amendment should be used to help businesses by actually doing away with some of the red tape. This has not yet happened. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcome this resolution because the recast for a regulation is aimed at codifying various acts applicable to road statistics and setting new conditions for the delegation of powers by the legislator to the Commission. It should be noted that the application of delegated powers must not cause any additional financial and administrative burden for statistical respondents. Consequently, Parliament must be given the right to set certain conditions to protect respondents from an additional burden. I believe that it is advisable to limit the powers delegated to the Commission and to set further conditions as regards the exercising of those powers. It is also crucial to ensure that the Commission carries out appropriate consultations during its preparatory work, including consultations with experts. The Commission should also keep Parliament appropriately informed and provide it with the necessary documents.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The statistical returns on the carriage of goods by road are needed in order to codify the various acts applicable to road statistics and to set new conditions for the delegation of transport powers. The recast of this regulation, as proposed by the rapporteur, which I voted in favour of, strikes a fair balance between the powers delegated to the Commission and to Parliament, in line with the similar approach taken for the regulation on tourism statistics.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for this report based on the opinion of the Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which concluded that the proposal in question does not include any substantive amendments other than those identified as such in the proposal, and that it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts, without any change in their substance.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: This proposal on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road is aimed, firstly, at codifying the existing provisions, which will undoubtedly be beneficial for legal certainty and security, as well as the accessibility of legal acts to EU citizens, and secondly, at setting out conditions for the delegation of powers by the EU legislator to the Commission, in line with Article 290 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. This is a laudable aim, as it seeks to ensure the appropriateness of EU law to its key texts. As such, I voted for the report.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The scope of the delegation of powers to the Commission is too broad in the proposed recast. At the same time, it is necessary to ensure that the application of delegated powers would not cause any additional substantial financial burden on statistical respondents. Therefore, and in line with the similar approach taken for the regulation on tourism statistics, we have adopted amendments aiming at limiting the scope of powers delegated to the Commission and setting further conditions to the exercising of those powers. Moreover, it is necessary to adjust some provisions on implementing acts with the new regulation on implementing acts which entered into force on 1 March 2011. Your rapporteur believes that the proposed amendments would be a good basis for further negotiations with the Council and the Commission. The recast procedure is governed by Rule 87 of the Rules of Procedure.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This report seeks to recast the regulation on statistical returns in respect of carriage of goods by road in order to codify a range of acts applicable to road transport statistics and, at the same time, to set new criteria for the delegation of powers. I completely agree with the standardisation of statistical data in order to clearly assess the different data provided by the Member States. However, I believe that this recasting should not impose any additional costs on statistical respondents, and that in the process of delegating powers to the Commission, Parliament should be kept appropriately informed. This same change should also be applied to tourism statistics.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the Simpson report on the proposal for a regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road. In order to fulfil the tasks which it has been assigned as part of the common transport policy, the Commission must have available comparable, reliable, synchronised, regulated and comprehensive returns about the scope and development of freight transport using vehicles registered in the EU, and about the level of use of the vehicles providing this transport. Comprehensive regional statistics need to be compiled on both freight transport and the trips made by the vehicles. According to the principle of subsidiarity, the standard common statistics which enable harmonised information to be obtained can be compiled better only at EU level. The data will be collected in each Member State under the authority of the bodies and institutions which are tasked with compiling official statistics. Member States must provide statistics on freight transport using freight transport vehicles registered in the relevant Member State and on the trips made by these vehicles. Member States shall supply Eurostat every quarter with separate, thoroughly verified returns, without indicating names, addresses or registration numbers.

intervention.name: Oldřich VLASÁK
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: The regulation on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road lays down the obligation of Member States to send data on the carriage of goods by road to Eurostat. I have no objections to this regulation, but I have some reservations concerning the delegation of powers to the European Commission for the adoption of implementing measures in the form of delegated acts. I also consider it important to consult on proposals at expert level when drawing up delegated acts, on the understanding that the Commission should ensure that the administrative burden on Member States and reporting units is not greatly increased.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The Commission has presented a proposal that involves the codification of several legal acts that can be applied to freight transport statistics. The rapporteur finds fault with the regulation of transfer powers, believing this to be too extensive and therefore proposing amendments that would again limit the scope of these powers. I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report, as I agree with the rapporteur, who believes that border areas are a very important tool, developed by the EU to ensure that artificial and arbitrary barriers are not erected between peoples living in regions divided by national frontiers. It is indeed important to encourage the Member States to conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries, with a view to the promotion of sustained contact between the peoples living on either side of the EU’s external frontiers.

intervention.name: Mara BIZZOTTO
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the inclusion of the Kaliningrad area and certain Polish administrative districts in the eligible border area. Since 2004, with the enlargement of the EU by 10 countries including Poland, the Kaliningrad region has become a de facto Russian enclave within the EU, which has brought about a profound change in living conditions for local citizens. The initiatives put into action have so far not led to a significant reduction in the marginalisation of the inhabitants of the region in question and the region itself; there was therefore an objective need to remedy this situation. I therefore agree that it is worthwhile amending the regulation on local border traffic. This would prevent the fragmentation of the region into various different districts and thereby enable the inhabitants of the region to enjoy facilitations for local border traffic. Accordingly, since I think easing the movement of people – as well as cultural, social and economic exchange – in this area is a good idea, I have voted in favour.

intervention.name: Vito BONSIGNORE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report by Mr Triantaphyllides. The adoption of Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 allows the European Union to operate a general waiver on local traffic at external land borders for persons living in a border area, understood to be the land within 30 km of the border. Member States can therefore allow people who live in border areas to enter the Union with just a local border permit, without needing to present any other documents, such as a visa. Poland and the Russian Federation put forward an amendment to the regulation in light of the special circumstances in the Kaliningrad region. Here, a region with around one million inhabitants that is totally surrounded by the EU except for the Baltic Sea is artificially divided into three districts: one subject to a local border traffic agreement with Poland, one to an agreement with Lithuania and one not subject to any agreement. Such an amendment would enable all inhabitants to enjoy facilitations for local border traffic and ensure the destruction of artificial and arbitrary barriers between the region’s residents.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation became an enclave within the EU as a consequence of EU enlargement in 2004 and since then, has had all its ties with its neighbours considerably circumscribed. There have been a number of EU initiatives in the past years which have facilitated the movement of Kaliningrad residents. However, given the specific geographical situation of Kaliningrad, such initiatives have proven insufficient in addressing the marginalisation of Kaliningrad and its residents. I welcome the Commission proposal amending the local border traffic regulation as a response to these exceptional circumstances.

intervention.name: David CASA
intervention.p: On 20 December 2006, the European Parliament adopted Regulation 1931/2006 which set rules regarding local border traffic at the external borders of Member States. This regulation aimed to prevent barriers to trade, social and cultural interchange or regional cooperation. The Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation lies within this Schengen region as a result of the EU enlargement in 2004 and since then, it has lost all of its previous ties with its neighbours. There have been many regulations easing the border and travel restrictions between Kaliningrad and the rest of Russia; however, such initiatives have not been successful. Due to this situation, Kaliningrad and Poland have both called for amendments to be made to the local border traffic regulations in order to make the entire Kaliningrad region a single border area. I support the rapporteur and believe that this amendment will allow for improved regional cooperation. Furthermore, this move will also benefit Poland’s tourism sector since the amendment will allow for easier access to local border traffic permits.

intervention.name: Carlos COELHO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad region is distinguished by a very specific geographical situation, as it became an enclave within the EU following EU enlargement in 2004, and having become totally surrounded by two EU Member States. It is therefore hugely important in terms of cooperation and exchange in the Baltic Sea area, so it is vital to ensure that EU borders do not act as a barrier to economic, regional, social and cultural cooperation with those neighbouring countries.

An agreement from 2007 already exists between the EU and Russia on facilitating the issuance of visas, while the local border traffic regulation provides more facilities that fit better with the specific needs for regular or even everyday travel of the people who live in a border area.

I believe that this proposal is essential in view of cross-border cooperation developed under the European Neighbourhood Policy, and that it will undoubtedly help to promote the strategic partnership between the EU and Russia, in addition to improving neighbourly relations between the two parties. However, it should be made clear that this was a unique solution found to the exceptional situation of the Kaliningrad region, and should in no way, therefore, serve as a precedent.

intervention.name: Christine DE VEYRAC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this text, which will enable Kaliningrad to be considered as one single border area with the EU and will help to strengthen the strategic partnership between the EU and Russia.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The area that is currently the Kaliningrad region, part of what was once East Prussia, is a Russian enclave within the European Union. In order to prevent the population from becoming isolated, it is proposed to facilitate the movement of its residents through the derogation of certain rules set out in the Schengen Borders Code, amending Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 for this purpose, and allowing their access to the neighbouring Polish regions. The unusual situation of this Russian region would appear to justify the exceptional nature of these measures and encourage dialogue with one of the EU’s most important partners, so I voted for their adoption.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: One of the main triumphs in the history of Europe has been the Schengen Agreement, which, by abolishing checks at the internal borders, made the free movement of people possible in the territory of signatory countries and promoted trade and tourism. However, this freedom of movement brought with it major responsibilities for these countries and compelled them to be connected in an effective way. The success of this agreement has been such that some countries that do not belong to the European Union have signed this agreement. A regulation called the Schengen Borders Code (SBC) was approved in order to regulate the monitoring of people crossing external borders. The small province of Kaliningrad, in the Russian Federation, is fully surrounded by two Member States, and since EU enlargement in 2004, has been the only enclave in the EU, so it should be classified as a local border traffic area under the SBC. This situation will help to foster the strategic partnership between the EU and the Russian Federation. I am therefore voting for the report presented by Mr Triantaphyllides on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006, and I welcome the inclusion of the Kaliningrad region and certain Polish administrative districts in the border area set out in the Schengen Agreement.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad region, an enclave of the Russian Federation on the coast of the Baltic Sea, has land borders only with EU countries, namely Poland and Lithuania, following the enlargement of the EU in 2004. Since then, it has had all its ties with its neighbouring countries considerably circumscribed.

There have been a number of EU initiatives in recent years aimed at facilitating the movement of Kaliningrad residents, such as the Facilitated Transit Document and the Facilitated Rail Transit Document. These initiatives have simplified travel between Kaliningrad and mainland Russia. In 2007, an agreement was also signed between the EU and Russia on visa facilitation, which facilitates the issuance of short-term visas for all Russian nationals travelling to Schengen countries. However, given the specific geographical situation of Kaliningrad, such initiatives have proven insufficient in addressing the marginalisation of Kaliningrad and its residents.

This is why both Poland and the Russian Federation have called for amendments to the local border traffic regulation, taking into account the specific situation of the Kaliningrad region. This report therefore seeks to give a response, which we believe to be appropriate and positive, to a persistent problem.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: We voted for this report by a Cypriot Member of this House from our political group because we believe it gives a positive response to a specific matter. The fact is that the Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation became an enclave within the EU as a consequence of the EU enlargement in 2004 and since then, has had all its ties with its neighbours considerably circumscribed.

There have been a number of EU initiatives in recent years aimed at facilitating the movement of Kaliningrad residents, such as the Facilitated Transit Document and the Facilitated Rail Transit Document, which have simplified travel between Kaliningrad and mainland Russia. In 2007, an agreement was also signed between the EU and Russia on visa facilitation, which facilitates the issuance of short-term visas for all Russian nationals travelling to Schengen countries. However, given the specific geographical situation of Kaliningrad, such initiatives have proven insufficient in addressing the marginalisation of Kaliningrad and its residents. This is why both Poland and the Russian Federation have called for amendments to the local border traffic regulation, taking into account the specific situation of the Kaliningrad region.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: In December 2006, the European Parliament and the Council adopted a regulation laying down rules on local border traffic at the external land borders of the Member States, which enables Member States to derogate from the general rules on border checks, including the visa requirement, the need to provide evidence of sufficient means of subsistence and the need to prove the purpose of the visit. The aim is to avoid the creation of obstacles preventing commercial, social and cultural exchanges or regional cooperation with neighbours. In implementing the local border traffic regime, a Member State may conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring countries aimed at addressing specific needs in relation to their respective neighbours. Ties between the Kaliningrad region and its neighbours were greatly circumscribed particularly as a result of the expansion of the Union in 2004. There have been a number of EU initiatives in the past which facilitated the movement of Kaliningrad residents, but these proved to be insufficient given the specific geographical situation of the enclave. Poland and the Russian Federation are therefore requesting a change to the regulation to take account of the specific situation of this region. The European Commission is inclined to take a positive view, as long as this only involves the resolution of an isolated situation. In my opinion, it is also desirable for Poland to adopt the necessary measures to ensure greater ease of movement and prevent unnecessary complications that would hinder this movement and would introduce new barriers.

intervention.name: Adam GIEREK
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of adopting the report, since as a Pole and as a member of the Delegation to the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, I am delighted by the announcement that there will be visa-free traffic over the border for the inhabitants of the Russian Kaliningrad Region and the Polish border areas. This is an achievement for my country, for the European Union as a whole, and, at the same time, also for Russia, in the spirit of opening ourselves up freely to each other for a better future.

It is not politicians who shape border contacts, but the open flow of ordinary citizens. With them comes economic and intellectual potential, which gives rise to the multifaceted development of border areas, ranging from tourism, through business, to culture. This is the reason for the great interest in my country in visa-free travel to Kaliningrad and the strong desire to include additional areas.

Unfortunately, the name of the Russian region, which is derived from Kalinin, a Soviet functionary who was an accomplice in the murder of Polish officers in Katyn, has negative associations in Poland. The traditional name Królewiec can be used in Poland for Kaliningrad to resolve this problem.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcomed this report because this measure will prevent the artificial fragmentation of a region of about 1 million inhabitants in total into three districts (one covered by a local border traffic agreement with Poland, one by an agreement with Lithuania and one without any agreement at all as it lies outside the border area) and enable all inhabitants, under the conditions laid out in the regulation, to take advantage of the simplification of local border traffic.

intervention.name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
intervention.p: I would like to express my full support for this report. One of the ideas behind the European Union is the free movement of persons, which is meant to promote relationships among people, as well as commercial and intellectual exchanges. Therefore, instead of setting up barriers, we should circumvent them. The Kaliningrad region is a unique enclave and, prior to the accession of Poland and Lithuania to the EU, the residents of border areas maintained close contacts in various spheres of life. It is understandable that we want to protect the Union’s external border; however, one should also take into account the exceptional nature of this situation, as in the case of Romania and Moldova or Slovakia, Poland and Ukraine. Special procedures for visa-free local traffic would enable the free development of trade and make life easier for the inhabitants of these areas, who have been deprived of the relationships they had built over many years. The statistics provide clear proof of how much this is needed.

intervention.name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: The people of Kaliningrad should enjoy as much freedom to travel to the EU as is appropriate according to the rules on the Schengen area. This Kaliningrad oblast has almost one million inhabitants, which creates problems on its own as regards abolishing standard border controls. The creation of the exception to the general Schengen rules only for Kaliningrad is a step that requires sincere and deep cooperation by the Russian Federation and the EU. Such cooperation is now diminishing, in light of Russia opening a new anti-missile radar station in Kaliningrad, as well as suggestions about possible withdrawal from the New Start Treaty and deployment of tactical missiles to the Kaliningrad area.

All these steps do not increase the mutual trust that is a prerequisite for any exception to the general rules on the Schengen area and checks on the external border of the EU. Therefore, while supporting the general idea of facilitating local border traffic from and to Kaliningrad, it seems appropriate to postpone the decision on this measure until mutual trust and cooperation as regards Kaliningrad are built between the Russian Federation and the EU and its Member States.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this report. Local border areas constitute a very important tool developed by the European Union to ensure artificial and arbitrary barriers are not erected between peoples living in regions divided by national frontiers

intervention.name: Clemente MASTELLA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Local border areas constitute a very important tool developed by the European Union to ensure that artificial and arbitrary barriers are not erected between peoples living in regions divided by national frontiers. We support the rapporteur, who is encouraging Member States to conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries aiming at the promotion of sustained contacts between the peoples living on either side of the European Union’s external frontiers. The 2004 enlargement has created an artificial barrier to long-standing cultural, social and economic ties between the inhabitants of the region at large. We therefore support the request to amend the regulation as formulated in the Commission proposal. This gives us an important chance to reiterate our strong commitment to the principle of freedom of movement and to support consistently and fervently the right of people to circulate freely. We therefore urge Poland to take concrete actions to ensure the facilitation of movement and avoid unnecessary delays or other routine complications which would de facto hinder the free movement of citizens in the Kaliningrad region.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This report is a very useful way to reiterate, in no uncertain terms, Parliament’s unconditional commitment to freedom of movement. With this in mind, as Mr Triantaphyllides rightly points out, the amendment to the regulation should be seen as ensuring that the entire Kaliningrad district is considered to be a single border area.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad region is marked by a very specific geographical situation, as it became an enclave within the EU following EU enlargement in 2004, and became totally surrounded by two EU Member States. It is therefore hugely important in terms of cooperation and exchange in the Baltic Sea area, so it is important to ensure that EU borders do not act as a barrier to economic, regional, social and cultural cooperation with those neighbouring countries. This proposal is very important in view of cross-border cooperation developed under the European Neighbourhood Policy, and it will undoubtedly help to promote the strategic partnership between the EU and Russia, in addition to improving neighbourly relations between the two parties.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation became a European Union enclave following the EU enlargement in 2004. There have been a certain number of EU initiatives in recent years to make it easier for people living in Kaliningrad to travel. However, given their very specific geographical situation, these initiatives have not been enough to prevent the region and its inhabitants from becoming marginalised. The aim of this report is to approve the European Commission proposal to review and, if necessary, extend these initiatives to help the inhabitants of Kaliningrad to travel to Europe. I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: The proposal seeks to make an exception to the regulation to allow the whole of the Kaliningrad oblast, as well as a wider area at the border with Poland, to be considered as a local border area. This will avoid fragmentation of existing administrative districts and ensure the inhabitants can move easily without visa requirements. I think this is a very good proposal and I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Radvilė MORKŪNAITĖ-MIKULĖNIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: With this unprecedented decision – amending a regulation according to the regional needs of a non-EU Member State – the EU is making a special gesture of goodwill towards Russia. I hope that this decision will contribute to developing people-to-people links, so that in the long term, the Kaliningrad region will become a polygon of European modernisation and an example for other Russian regions. I hope that in response, the Russian Federation will strengthen cooperation with relevant EU Member States in areas such as combating organised crime and smuggling (particularly cigarettes produced in the Kaliningrad region and fuel), so that finally, we can anticipate cooperation as regards plans to construct nuclear power plants in the Kaliningrad region and progress in joint projects such as the Nemunas Euroregion. I would also like to remind you that the Kaliningrad region plays a special role in Russian military strategy. While I know that this is a prelude to larger scale decisions, I would point out that a visa waiver is not an EU obligation but a decision based on the progress and reforms made by the country requesting it, which would enable it to be introduced safely. I find it hard to imagine that visa requirements can be lifted in relation to a country whose state structures protect people who are guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity, as is the case with Mikhail Golovatov, nor at a time when Russia refuses to cooperate in such categories of cases as those that took place on 13 January and the Medininkai killings. I therefore hope that Russia will also offer a genuine strategic partnership. It is equally important not to leave behind ENPI countries such as Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, which are making significant progress in implementing European reforms.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcome this resolution because we must eliminate artificial and arbitrary barriers for people living on both sides of the European Union’s external borders. The Member States have a special role to play in this case and must conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries as a matter of urgency. The implementation of these measures will create a favourable environment for the development of long-term cultural, social and economic links between the inhabitants of the entire region. I believe that this new recast regulation will help to establish better neighbourly relations between the EU and Russia. Moreover, it is clear proof that the EU is respecting its commitment to implementing the principle of freedom of movement and to consistently and actively support people’s right to free movement.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on amending the regulation for residents of European Union border areas because, both for neighbouring Member States and for citizens of third countries living along the borders, it is important to facilitate border crossings without the need for visas or any special checks. It is important to implement a regulation that is adapted to the needs of the citizens of these territories, so that they may enjoy a quiet life, and in order to ease both their private lives and commercial ties between small businesses of the areas in question. In particular, the regulation looks at the inclusion in these zones, as outlined above, of the Kaliningrad region and some border territories of Poland.

intervention.name: Georgios PAPANIKOLAOU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad area, which forms part of the Russian Federation, became an enclave within the EU as a consequence of EU enlargement in 2004 and, since then, has had its ties with neighbouring countries considerably circumscribed. Despite European initiatives to improve the movement of Kaliningrad residents, the specific geographical situation of the area has not prevented the marginalisation of Kaliningrad and its residents. With the present proposal to amend the relevant regulation, and based on Article 15 of the regulation allowing the Member States to introduce measures aimed at easing border crossings for holders of local border traffic permits, the report, which I supported, calls on neighbouring countries (in this case Poland) to take all the necessary measures, such as, for example, the establishment of special border crossings or lanes dedicated exclusively to holders of local border traffic permits, in order to facilitate movements and eliminate the conditions that prevent this traffic and raise new obstacles.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This report is based on the legislative resolution of Parliament, of 1 December 2011, amending the regulation on the inclusion of the Kaliningrad region and certain Polish administrative districts in the eligible border area. The aim is that these regions will benefit from the regulation that sets out rules for local border traffic on the land borders of the Member States and amends the provisions of the Schengen Agreement. This measure prevents the creation of barriers to social and cultural interchange and regional cooperation with neighbours, as well as preventing the creation of barriers to trade, while also preserving the security of the entire Schengen area. I voted in favour for these reasons.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerns rules on local border traffic at the external borders of the Member States, which enables them to derogate from the rules on border checks for neighbouring countries, as it is not necessary to present a visa, proof of sufficient means of subsistence or proof of the purpose of the stay in these exceptional cases. This derogation from the regulation is based on the desire to ensure good relations between peoples, without centuries-old economic, social and cultural ties between the different communities coming undone. This is the case in the region of Kaliningrad, called Königsberg in German, which was part of the Soviet Union between 1945 and 1992, and since then has belonged to the Russian Federation, with a natural border with the Baltic Sea, and land borders with Poland and Lithuania. Extending the border area up to 50 km, from the 30 km cited in the regulation, is therefore justified, in order to avoid the breakdown of a single region into several artificial areas.
As such, I voted in favour, in the hope that the agreement will help to facilitate relations between the two spaces, which were been hampered by the EU enlargement in 2004.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. On 20 December 2006, the European Parliament and Council adopted Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 laying down rules on local border traffic at the external land borders of the Member States (hereafter: the regulation), which enables Member States to derogate from the general rules on border checks laid down in the Schengen Borders Code for persons living in a border area, including visa requirement, the need to have sufficient means of subsistence as well as the need to prove the purpose of the stay. The objective of this regulation is to prevent the creation of barriers to trade, social and cultural interchange or regional cooperation with neighbours.

intervention.name: Tokia SAÏFI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad enclave is the only one on European Union territory. In 2006, the Council and the European Parliament adopted a regulation laying down rules on local border traffic at the external land borders of the Member States, which enables Member States to derogate from the general rules on border checks laid down in the Schengen Borders Code for persons living in a border area. Under the regulation, Member States may conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring countries that are not members of the European Union. Local border traffic makes life much easier for persons living close to external land borders. There is little evidence of abuse. Applying the rules that are normally used to define border areas would artificially divide this enclave. This text authorises the enlargement of the ‘border area’, thereby facilitating and increasing the amount of economic and cultural exchanges between Kaliningrad, on the one hand, and the main centres in northern Poland, on the other. I voted in favour of this modification to the regulation as I believe that European legislation and regulations must be adapted to the realities on the ground.

intervention.name: Sergio Paolo Francesco SILVESTRIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation became an enclave within the EU as a consequence of the EU enlargement in 2004 and since then, has had its ties with its neighbours considerably circumscribed. There have been a number of EU initiatives in the last few years to facilitate the movement of Kaliningrad residents. Among the various measures that have been adopted, there is the establishment of a Facilitated Rail Transit Document for travel between Kaliningrad and mainland Russia. Furthermore, in 2007, the EU and Russia entered into the Visa Facilitation Agreement, which simplifies the issuance of short-term visas for all Russian nationals travelling to Schengen countries. Local border areas constitute a very important tool developed by the European Union to ensure that artificial and arbitrary barriers are not erected between peoples living in regions divided by national frontiers. Member States must therefore conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries with the objective of promoting sustained contacts between the peoples living on either side of the European Union’s external frontiers.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The expansion of the EU means that the Kaliningrad area in the Russian Federation has become an enclave within the EU. Around 1 million people live in three districts completely surrounded by EU territory. These people now encounter stringent transit and visa requirements when they wish to travel to Poland or to the main part of Russia. Council Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006 sets down rules for local border traffic and external land borders of Member States (relating to a zone of 30 km) that are an exception to the provisions of the Schengen Agreement. In order to implement this regulation, the affected countries can conclude bilateral agreements with neighbouring third countries in order to take the special conditions sufficiently into account. The EU has introduced initiatives in an effort to make it easier for those living in the area to commute between Kaliningrad and the Russian mainland. Thus far, however, these initiatives have proven inadequate. Poland and the Russian Federation have now petitioned for an amendment to Council Regulation (EC) No 1931/2006: as an exception, the border area is to be extended to 50 km so that the whole Kaliningrad area would be designated a border area. The Commission recommends that the regulation should be amended accordingly. I have also voted in favour.

intervention.name: Zbigniew ZIOBRO
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: The report we have voted on reveals an unequal treatment of partners. All residents of the Kaliningrad region have the opportunity of crossing the border; meanwhile, on the Polish side, only a 50 km wide section of the border area is covered by the visa-free travel programme. This harmful inequality must be resolved by extending the zone to cover the entire voivodship, and by discussing this issue at the next EU-Russia meeting.

Unfortunately, the resolution also fails to mention the possibility of the movement of commercial and tourist vessels through the Pilawa Strait onto the Vistula Spit. Currently, the Russian side wants to limit the right of innocent passage with regard to the category of the straits. I think that we as the Union should seek to compensate for inequalities in the treatment of the inhabitants of the regions bordering the Kaliningrad region and provide the entire population of the voivodship, not just of selected districts, with the opportunity to enter the Kaliningrad region freely.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for the conclusion of the Treaty concerning the Accession of Croatia, and I see this treaty as a positive political factor in European integration. I would, however, draw attention to the need to strengthen European policies aimed at cohesion and the socio-economic and territorial convergence of the EU, without which, EU enlargement may have undesirable results.

intervention.name: Roberta ANGELILLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I abstained in the vote on Croatia’s request to join the European Union. There is no doubt that Croatia has made significant progress in recent years on reforming its legal system and public administration, fighting corruption and organised crime, and protecting the rights of minorities. However, I am sure that much remains to be done in remembrance of the huge ethnic cleansing of the Italian population carried out between 1945 and 1948 by the militia of the Croatian authorities of the former Yugoslavian communist regime. Above all, no commitment has been made to recognise the rights of exiles, starting with the property that was confiscated during those years.

intervention.name: Pino ARLACCHI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I voted for this resolution because I fully support the conclusion of the accession negotiations for EU membership with Croatia. I believe that Croatian membership will make the EU stronger, will enrich its culture, and will make an important contribution giving a positive impetus to the process of European integration. I also would like to stress the need for Croatia to keep up the reform momentum and to continue with the same vigour and hard work also after the conclusion of the negotiations and beyond accession. While acknowledging the good progress made, Croatia should continue to implement reform of the judiciary and facilitate the return of refugees and displaced persons, paying special attention to the situation of ethnic Serbian returnees. In addition to that, Croatian authorities should strengthen the administrative capacities of anti-corruption bodies and foster a culture of political, public sector and judicial accountability as a prerequisite for reinforcing the rule of law.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The process for Croatia’s accession to the EU began in 2003 when the country submitted its application to the European Commission. The last 10 years of negotiations have enabled it to prepare for membership of the European Union. I welcome the support given by the European Parliament, which sought to send a strong signal to Croatia. The country will become the 28th member of the EU on 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: Zoltán BAGÓ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Croatia’s EU accession negotiations have been ongoing for six years. The Group of the European People’s Party and Hungary strongly supported Croatia’s accession during these negotiations. With my vote, I, too, expressed the fact that I agree with the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union and with the Council decision accepting the application for accession.

The Council formulated the draft Accession Treaty in agreement with Hungary. Hungarian interests have been incorporated into the document over the course of a drafting process which lasted more than one year. According to the schedule, Croatia may become the 28th EU Member State as of 1 July 2013.

However, I would like to stress the need for further cooperation on the part of Croatia with the ICTY (the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia), for increasing the efficiency of the justice system, and for continuing the fight against corruption and organised crime.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: I welcome the enlargement of the European Union through the accession of the Republic of Croatia. Croatia has prepared very well for accession, which implies lasting respect for the values on which the EU is based, as well as a commitment to promoting them. Croatia fulfils the political criteria, and it is expected that this country will meet the economic criteria and those of the acquis for its accession on 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: David CASA
intervention.p: Croatia has been an independent nation for twenty years now and an EU accession candidate for eight. The country has successfully met the required criteria to become a fully-fledged Member State. The accession process has helped consolidate democracy and has mobilised other sweeping political, social and economic reforms in Croatia. The nation’s accession is important both to the EU and to the Balkan region in general. I support the rapporteur and believe that Croatia should be accepted as a Member State on 1 July 2013 as long as it continues the improvements made thus far. Until this date, I encourage Croatia to continue to step up its prosecution of war criminals, better facilitate the return of refugees, improve women’s equality in regard to equal pay and representation in political institutions and improve LGBT rights due to the violence demonstrated at the LGBT pride march in June 2011.

intervention.name: Ioan ENCIU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the European Union as I feel that this country has met all the conditions, both political and economic, to be able to become a member of the EU. Croatia’s accession helps the European Union prove that it remains receptive and capable of maintaining a genuine, constructive dialogue with its immediate neighbours. This is an extremely important consideration, especially during the current crisis the EU is going through, forcing it to become introverted. Dialogue and openness, both fundamental values of the EU, must remain benchmarks not only in its external relations and in issues such as immigration, but also with regard to internal European dynamics. This dialogue and openness should help kick-start the EU’s integration by rejecting nationalistic or xenophobic behaviour.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this recommendation as it advocates the accession of Croatia to the European Union. This opens the way to the signing of the Treaty of Accession on 8 December, and its subsequent ratification by the 27 Member States. However, Croatia needs to address the challenges that it is currently facing, in particular, with regard to its judicial system and the fight against corruption and organised crime.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In February 2010, I wrote that Croatia had been undeniably successful in fulfilling the criteria for membership, and that it had made an effort to continue along this path, despite the additional difficulties that it had to face in view of the international situation, and that Croatia was a good example for other countries wishing to become part of the European Union. Fortunately, Croatia has not deviated from this path, so that, in accordance with the criteria established by the EU, it is now ready to join this community of Member States and peoples. I welcome the Croatian people and their institutions at this important time in its history and in our common European history, and I hope that Croatia’s accession to the EU will provide a new impetus for reform to the Balkan countries that are not yet part of the EU, and to the EU itself.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: This proposal for a recommendation, drafted by Mr Swoboda, focuses on the Treaty concerning the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, one of the three instruments that make up the process of accession of a country to the EU: treaty, protocol and final act. The accession of Croatia to the EU is a moment of great importance for Europe, and represents another step forward in the process of bringing stability to the Balkans. For Croatia, this phase does not represent the end of the process, but only the successful completion of one more stage. I would point out that this accession is an historic moment for Europe, as was evident in the enthusiasm with which Parliament applauded the adoption of the proposal for Croatia’s accession. As we are looking at a ‘happy marriage’ – the EU has an interest in its enlargement into the Balkans, and Croatia has much to gain from its accession to the single market – I welcome the accession of Croatia to the EU and hope that the Croatian Government will continue the process of democratisation and reform that is already under way, thus contributing to the principles which underlie the construction of the single market.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: The decision on Croatia’s accession, or that of any other country, to the European Union must come, first and foremost, from the free expression of the sovereign will of this country’s people. This is all the more important in the knowledge that this free expression – which, of course, involves a deep, participatory and informed discussion and decision – was not always ensured in other cases in the past.

We should neither ignore nor underestimate the meaning, nature and aims of this process of integration. The experience of other countries, including Portugal, shows us that the process of capitalist integration embodied by the EU involves the destruction of productive capacity and employment, the country’s increasing dependence, a disadvantageous, subordinated position which is peripheral to the process of the international division of labour, the loss of sovereignty over key elements which would have allowed our people to realise their wishes and aspirations, and which are absolutely essential to their free collective self-determination.

However, the internationalisation of the economy, the international division of labour, the growing cooperation between Member States and the processes of integration correspond to realities and trends of development which are not unique to capitalism. We are therefore fighting for this other Europe – a Europe that is not only possible, but also increasingly necessary.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: It is up to the Croatian people, in the first place, to make the decision as to whether or not to join the EU. The Portuguese experience shows us that the EU’s process of capitalist integration has meant, and still means, first and foremost, the destruction of productive capacity and employment, the growing dependence of the country on the major powers of the EU, and a loss of sovereignty on key elements that would have allowed our people to realise their wishes and aspirations.

As the integration of economies is a dialectical necessity, its development within the framework of the capitalist system and the unequal development that this entails only favours the major powers and monopolies, particularly financial monopolies, impoverishing countries and peoples, sacrificing democracy and impeding the fight for economic and social systems that make work and human wellbeing their first and only priority.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: Twenty years after declaring independence, and almost eight years after applying for membership of the EU, Croatia has reached an historic milestone, with the successful completion of the accession talks and the country now in the process of joining the EU, and these successes deserve unconditional acknowledgement. The accession process is making a substantial contribution to Croatia’s transformation into a solid and mature democratic country whose membership can strengthen the Union, enrich its European culture and heritage and make a major contribution to preserving the credibility of the expansion process. Despite considerable progress, however, I firmly believe that it is important to continue with the reforms initiated, that it is necessary to focus particularly on commitments undertaken in the area of the judiciary, internal affairs and basic rights – including the protection of media freedom, the impartial resolution of war crimes cases, the fight against corruption, protection of minorities, border controls, police cooperation, the fight against organised crime and judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters – as well as on commitments undertaken in the area of competition policy. Croatia’s determination to combat corruption, and also the progress achieved in the area of women’s rights and gender equality, for example, are pleasing. It is desirable for Croatia to continue consolidating good neighbourly relations, to continue as an important and active promoter of regional cooperation at all levels, and to back up its efforts towards membership with steps that will be economically, socially and generally beneficial to all citizens of this region.

intervention.name: Pat the Cope GALLAGHER
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
