intervention.p: I fully support the accession of Croatia to the European Union. The next step is for the Member States and for Croatia, following a national referendum, to sign the Accession Treaty. It is thought that Croatia will accede to the EU on 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
intervention.p: Croatia is, without doubt, a European country by dint of its geography, culture, history and population. We should all welcome the fact that we have been able to maintain a close relationship with the country. However, the European project as it stands cannot be the framework for this relationship. It is, in fact, developing into a centralised, supranational state, bypassing the peoples and the national parliaments, imposing its ultraliberal, globalist diktats, and conferring on itself the right to dictate the budgets of the Member States and, as a consequence, all of their actions, with its eyes firmly fixed on satisfying the markets rather than on people’s wellbeing. I understand the symbolic value, for the people of Croatia, of accession to the European Union. However, I also know that they will soon become disenchanted. The benefits that they will derive from membership will be far fewer than they had hoped, and the restrictions far more intolerable than they had expected. Ask the Greeks, the Irish and the Portuguese what they think about it now. I would not sell any of my friends a ticket to board the Titanic. That is why I abstained.

intervention.name: Mathieu GROSCH
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I abstained from voting on the report because although the country has already made enormous efforts, it has not managed to meet the necessary criteria.

The EU should be making every effort to work together more effectively and to strengthen its social and economic policy, rather than admitting new members and giving rise to false hopes in these countries, as it did, for example, in those countries that most recently joined the EU. This may make Europe bigger, but it will certainly not succeed in making it better or stronger.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcomed this document and the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia and, notably, the Council decision accepting the application for accession, but the Commission must monitor further preparations for accession with rigour and objectivity and help the Croatian authorities fulfil the commitments and obligations they entered into in the negotiations. The Commission must also keep Parliament regularly informed of the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments in order to fully assume their membership obligations upon accession to the EU on 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted against Croatian admission to the EU at this time.

intervention.name: Clemente MASTELLA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: We take the view that the conditions set out for the admission of Croatia to the European Union have been completely met. Parliament must be consulted on any substantial modifications to the draft Treaty. We also think that the Commission will play a crucial role by carefully, rigorously and objectively monitoring further preparations for accession and by helping the Croatian authorities to fulfil the commitments and obligations assumed during negotiations. We expect the Commission to keep Parliament regularly informed of the measures taken by the Croatian authorities to honour their commitments and to fully assume their membership obligations upon accession, scheduled for 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: Véronique MATHIEU HOUILLON
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I abstained from the vote on Croatia’s application for accession to the European Union. Indeed, this report consents to the Republic of Croatia becoming a member of the European Union. Although the Commission is required to report regularly to Parliament on the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments in order to fulfil the obligations incumbent on them when Croatia joins the EU on 1 July 2013, I personally believe that the crisis that the European Union is experiencing is sufficiently serious as to suspend the accession process. The European Union’s current Member States, in particular, those in the euro area, must be in a strong enough position to accommodate a new member, with all the advantages and disadvantages it will bring. The current efforts of the Heads of State or Government to build the future of the EU are evidence of the urgent need to consolidate our acquis . Moreover, I would expect the European Commission to take special measures to obtain guarantees regarding the fight against corruption.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In light of the fact that Croatia has now shown that it meets the accession requirements, I am in favour of approving the accession request. I would add that this is a truly important event for the European Union and for the entire Balkans area.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: I voted for the accession of Croatia to the European Union. It meets all the criteria for accession to the EU, dubbed the Copenhagen criteria: the existence of the Rule of Law, stable institutions that ensure democracy, respect for human rights and the protection of minorities, the existence of a functioning market economy, and the ability to cope with competitive pressure and EU market forces. As it is able to meet the obligations of membership, including sharing the objectives of the political, economic and monetary union, Croatia’s joining the 27 Member States also symbolises the solidarity of the EU in its efforts to send a positive signal to the Balkans.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: My group has always been in favour of Croatia and any other country being able to join the European Union, as long as they fulfil the established requirements. This is why I voted in favour of this report, because it approves Croatia’s accession to the EU.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Since its independence, Croatia has shown its desire to build a solid relationship with the European Union. This is demonstrated by the reform of its administrative system and its ever greater efforts to combat corruption. Croatia must continue with these efforts, as its accession, scheduled for July 2013, is not the end of the process, but rather the start of a long and increasingly close relationship. A support mechanism will have to be maintained as part of a relationship of trust between the European Union and Croatia. This will ensure that the details of Croatia’s accession are favourable to each party. In the future, Zagreb will have to make further efforts to combat corruption and organised crime, among other things; it will have to tackle the issue of legal reforms, prosecute war criminals, encourage the return of refugees and ensure compliance with all of the recommendations of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY). As Mr Barroso so rightly said, enlargement is a question of credibility. I am convinced that Croatia will be a credible and trustworthy 28th Member State.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I welcome the signing of Croatia’s Accession Treaty and regard it as proof of credibility of EU enlargement policy: hard work and reforms take some time, but pay off ultimately! S&D is looking forward to the arrival of Croatian observers to the EP. In favour.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: The accession of Croatia to the European Union is an important step. In recent years, Croatia has worked continuously to implement the reforms demanded by the EU in the accession negotiations and to thereby meet all the accession criteria. In addition, there can be no doubt that Croatia is part of the European cultural community characterised by a Christian tradition, so that integration in the European Union would seem to be desirable. It should also be emphasised that, unlike Turkey, Croatia has always pushed forward with the promised reforms. This would indicate that the inclusion of the people of Croatia will give the EU another Member State it can rely upon at European level. The accession of Croatia is also an important step towards the integration of the countries of the Western Balkans. For these reasons, I have voted in favour of Croatia’s accession.

intervention.name: Vital MOREIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the European Union as I believe that this country completely fulfils the condition for membership of the Union, starting with the Copenhagen criteria, which are now explicitly mentioned in the Treaty on European Union, in particular, with regard to democracy, human rights, an independent judiciary, good governance, protection of minorities, market economy and competition, social protection, and so on.

Following the early accession of Bulgaria and Romania, which were clearly not yet ready to do so, it has been important to ensure that new countries that join are better prepared and less swayed by political expediency. The EU has already had too many problems in trying to spare itself the difficulties of coping with the entry of new countries that do not meet the conditions necessary for full integration into all areas of European integration, such as the internal market, social Europe, the area of freedom, security and justice, and external policy.

intervention.name: Radvilė MORKŪNAITĖ-MIKULĖNIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Today, the European Parliament adopted an historic decision, consenting to the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia and the Council decision accepting Croatia’s application for accession. I hope that Croatia will continue to keep up the good progress it has made in meeting the commitments it entered into during the negotiations. I am pleased that Lithuania, the country I come from, and Croatia will be linked by history given that Croatia’s accession to the EU is due to take place on 1 July 2013 during Lithuania’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union. I hope that here in the European Parliament, we will soon be able to congratulate our parliamentary observer colleagues from Croatia.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcome this resolution, which consents to the accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia. However, the Commission must continue to monitor further preparations for accession with rigour and objectivity. Croatia must guarantee the stability of institutions safeguarding democracy, the rule of law and human rights and properly satisfy economic and legal requirements. Consequently, it is very important to ensure that the Croatian authorities are given full assistance so that they are able to properly fulfil the commitments and obligations they entered into during the negotiations.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Parliament has approved the Council’s recommendation on the admission of Croatia to the EU, thanks, in part, to my vote in favour. After eight years of negotiations, we have finally arrived at the decisive moment when the Croatian people will decide in a referendum next year whether their country will be part of the EU from 2013 onwards. Croatia must be recognised for having reached an historic goal in its process of integration, successfully concluding accession negotiations with the EU after having satisfied requirements in relation to the legal system, the protection of fundamental rights and fighting corruption. All these achievements are worthy of unreserved recognition.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union as, based on the reports presented to Parliament, I believe that the conditions for the admission of the candidate country have been fulfilled. I would, however, point out the Commission’s duty to monitor the remaining preparations for accession closely and objectively, and to help the Croatian authorities meet the commitments and obligations that they took on in the negotiations. I would also highlight the need for the Commission to keep Parliament regularly informed about the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments, so that they can take on all their obligations as a Member State when the country joins the EU on 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: I voted for the approval of Croatia’s accession to the European Union as all of the conditions for accession to the common area are found to have been met, and the Committee on Foreign Affairs has not raised any objections.

intervention.name: Frédérique RIES
intervention.p: By consenting to Croatia’s accession to the European Union, the European Parliament has paved the way for the start of the country’s accession process and its ratification by the 27 Member States of the current European club. This agreement should be ratified at the European Council on 9 December with a view to Croatia’s official accession on 1 July 2013. Of course, now is not the time to hold celebrations such as those that marked the enlargement ceremonies held when 10 new countries joined the Union on 1 June 2004. However, it is important to welcome this jewel of the Mediterranean in a fitting manner; in other words, enthusiastically and firmly. A spontaneous accession, rather than accession by default, is needed, given the efforts made by Croatia’s people, and given, too, its standard of living and the economic situation in Croatia, both of which are much better than the indicators for other countries were when they joined. The crisis that has reigned in the Union since 2009 also implies the need for a firm stance towards new members, who have to become part of a virtuous circle: tight budgets and relentless efforts to combat corruption and to promote transparency. This, too, is a message that the Croatian authorities must hear.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The EP has today given its broad support to Croatian membership, recognising the huge progress made towards reforms by Croatia. The process of reform is not over, however, and Croatia should continue on its reform path. This is particularly true in the areas of justice reform, anti-corruption reforms, minority protection and the prosecution of war crimes. The EP has today also criticised the crackdown on the last Gay Pride Parade in Split, in spite of efforts by the EPP to muzzle this criticism. The EP must now continue to monitor the situation to ensure Croatia implements all reforms and that the EU Commission properly oversees this. To this end, the Greens believe the EP should be given the role of assessing the 6-monthly monitoring reports on Croatia’s progress. MEPs also have an important role to convince EU citizens that continuing the enlargement process in the Western Balkans is in the interest of all in Europe.

intervention.name: Tokia SAÏFI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In the last few years, Croatia, which has been in accession negotiations with the European Union since 2005, has implemented radical structural reforms enabling it to meet EU membership requirements. Major reforms have been carried out with a view to promoting job creation, increasing competitiveness and strengthening fiscal policies. Many challenges remain, and the Croatian authorities must continue their reforms, particularly their judicial reforms, to combat corruption and organised crime. In order to heal the wounds of the past, Croatia needs to redouble its efforts to prosecute war criminals, follow the set of recommendations made by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and encourage the return of war refugees, especially the Serbs. Croatia’s forthcoming accession is a positive signal for the region as a whole; it is a sign that reforms pay, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: József SZÁJER
intervention.p: As we all remember, the EU accession of Croatia was a special priority of the Hungarian EU Presidency programme. Therefore, at this historic moment when we decided with an overwhelming majority in favour of Croatia becoming a full Member State of the EU, I consider it particularly important to highlight the immense efforts made by the Hungarian Presidency for the conclusion of the accession negotiations.

I am pleased to note that the Hungarians’ commitment has borne fruit. With the European Parliament approving Croatia’s accession today, we have opened a new chapter in the life of the EU. Enlargement is undeniable proof of the strength of European integration. At the same time, we must not forget that the ratification of the Accession Treaty by the Member States, and the Croatian referendum, still lie before us; however, if everything proceeds as planned, Croatia may join the European Union in July 2013.

I am of the opinion that today’s decision is beneficial for all parties concerned. Accession is not only of enormous significance for Croatia, but is also of strategic importance for Hungary and all the countries in the region. At the same time, I also hope that this enlargement will be able to give new impetus to the EU project as well.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Croatia’s accession to the European Union is a very positive sign for the Balkans. Croatia has achieved the set of political and economic criteria set out at the Copenhagen European Council in 1993, as well as the adaptation and implementation of the EU acquis , as described in the Commission’s opinion of October 2011.

The accession of Croatia to the EU on 1 July 2013 will set an example for other Balkan countries, showing that efforts to comply with the Copenhagen criteria can bear fruit. In the specific case of Croatia, issues such as the fight against corruption, the independent judiciary, and the pursuit of war criminals and cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia has led to negotiations dragging on since 2003, when Croatia made its first request to join the EU.
I congratulate the Croatian authorities for their efforts, but I would also like to emphasise that the rules should be equally applied to all candidate and potential candidate countries.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the European Parliament legislative resolution of 1 December 2011 on the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union because I support the Republic of Croatia’s accession to the European Union. The Commission must continue to monitor the preparations for accession rigorously and objectively and assist the Croatian authorities in meeting their commitments and obligations, as assumed during the negotiations. Furthermore, the Commission must inform Parliament on a regular basis about the extent to which the Croatian authorities are honouring their commitments, with a view to assuming fully the obligations arising from being a member when it joins, on 1 July 2013. We should point out that Parliament has to be consulted on any substantial modification to the draft Treaty on the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. We are expecting more active participation from Croatia as of 1 July 2013 in the development and implementation of the EU’s macro-regional strategies, especially the EU strategy for the Danube region.

intervention.name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: While I am generally in favour of enlargement of the EU, it is clear that the lessons of other recent accessions have not been learned. In relation to Croatia, there is still widespread corruption, organised crime has not been dealt with, the judiciary is often ineffective and property and contract laws do not function properly. On this basis, I abstained on these votes.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: According to Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union, the European Parliament must agree to any expansion of the European Union. I voted in favour because Croatia meets the Copenhagen criteria for full membership of the Union. Until the country’s definitive accession, the Commission will continue to monitor the development of the initiated reform process and report on this to the European Parliament.

intervention.name: Hermann WINKLER
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The EU has undergone a period of rapid growth in recent years. Twelve new Member States have acceded since 2004. Unfortunately, all the euphoria at the expansion in the East has meant that warnings have been ignored, as in the case of Bulgaria and Romania recently. As a result of the debt crisis, the EU is currently undergoing its greatest test since its foundation. Consolidation must take precedence over expansion if we are to preserve the European project. A ‘no’ at this point is not aimed at the Croatian people and the efforts of large parts of the population, but rather a vote in favour of stabilising the Union. For these reasons, I have voted against the accession of Croatia.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report. Croatia should continue with its reforms, in particular, in relation to the fight against corruption and the integration of refugees. The conclusion of the new accession process and the principle of ratifying the Treaty of Accession should in no way impede the reforms that are under way.

intervention.name: Zoltán BAGÓ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The conclusion of Croatia’s accession negotiations marks the end of a six-year process. According to the resolution, the European Parliament supports the signing of the Accession Treaty and I, too, have expressed the same opinion with my positive vote.

The conclusion of Croatia’s accession negotiations strengthens the credibility of the EU enlargement process, while the prospect of extending European integration facilitates peace in third countries and the establishment of good neighbourhood relations. In the Western Balkans region, there is still a great need for this today, especially during an economic crisis of this magnitude.

During the process of accession, it is extremely important for a country to be judged on the basis of its own achievements, and that Member States refrain from allowing bilateral disputes to influence the process.

I agree that Croatia still needs to fulfil its commitments made during the negotiations, for example, in respect of internal affairs, the reform of the judicial system, and fundamental rights. In the fight against corruption, it should strengthen the capacities of its administrative bodies.

intervention.name: Regina BASTOS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Twenty years after its declaration of independence, and roughly eight years since it submitted its application for membership to the EU, Croatia has successfully completed negotiations for EU membership. While the accession process has played a significant role in the transformation of Croatia into a solid democracy, Croatia’s accession will also make the EU stronger and will have broad implications at European and regional level, giving a positive boost to the process of European integration both in the EU and in the Western Balkans.

This report, for which I voted, emphasises the need for Croatia to maintain momentum in its reforms, keeping up the same intensity and determination following the conclusion of negotiations and accession. It encourages Croatia to continue to carry out its reform of the judiciary, in line with the recommendations of the Commission. However, the Croatian authorities should continue to increase the administrative capacity of bodies that are fighting against corruption, particularly with regard to best practice in the EU.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: I welcome the conclusion of accession negotiations with Croatia, putting an end to almost six years of negotiations and several years of preparation, which have changed the socio-political, economic and cultural landscape of the country considerably. It is necessary to maintain the momentum of reforms, as this process is not complete. I would call for the same intensity and determination to be maintained following the conclusion of negotiations and accession.

intervention.name: Carlos COELHO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The enlargement of the EU is one of the most effective instruments of its external policy and one of the best proofs of its success. Several countries want to join the EU, and none want to leave. During its history, the EU has grown from six to 27 Member States, and this has created some problems for the way in which it functions. I agree with the many who therefore argue that it is important that the three Copenhagen criteria be supplemented by a fourth: knowing whether the EU is able to integrate another candidate country.

In addition to there being doubts about Croatia’s readiness in some areas of the Rule of Law, I consider it unwise, especially in this time of crisis, to overstretch the EU by increasing the number of Member States. I would also point out that unanimity is required, especially when amending the Treaties, which have been discussed a great deal recently. I cannot therefore vote for the recommendation on Croatia’s accession to the EU at this point.

intervention.name: Lara COMI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: The accession of Croatia to the European Union from 1 July 2013 is the apotheosis of eight years of negotiations that deserve the utmost recognition, given the transformation of Croatia into a robust and mature democracy based on the founding values of the European Union. I hope that Croatia’s accession will act as a catalyst for reform in the Western Balkan countries. This event will enable Croatia and its citizens to take full advantage of the rights and guarantees provided for by the EU Treaties. Beyond these rights, the Croatian authorities must respect the commitments it has taken in the negotiations and encourage representatives of civil society to play a role in the entire accession process. Meanwhile, further support through the pre-accession instrument ought to facilitate adaptation to the reforms that are undertaken. However, my vote in favour of this report also serves to emphasise the need to proceed with the reforms geared towards ensuring that the magistracy is impartial and transparent on all forms of corruption and international organised crime. I would also encourage tighter cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY), particularly in terms of the pursuit of war criminals and the integration of political refugees.

intervention.name: Christine DE VEYRAC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Croatia’s accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, which is supported by the European Parliament, will make it possible to strengthen the EU area of prosperity and stability in South-East Europe, a region that witnessed the last open conflict on European soil. Croatia’s accession will help to maintain the credibility of the enlargement process and will serve as an encouragement for the other countries in the Western Balkans region that are on the path to European integration.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I would like to reiterate what I said in 2010: I hope that the entry of Croatia into the European Union will be seen in the Balkans as a sign of hope, and that the other countries in the region, particularly Serbia, will recognise the national and international advantages and benefits of opting for Europe. Given the objective confirmation that Croatia has complied with the criteria for accession, it is time to accept its request for entry into the EU and welcome Croatians to our common ‘family’. At a time that is not proving easy for any country in Europe, it is reassuring to see that the generous idea underlying our process of integration is still able to attract other European countries, and that, despite its problems, the European way is the best route for us to take together.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: This report, drafted by Mr Swoboda, focuses on Croatia’s application, which merits the agreement of the Council, as does the draft Treaty concerning the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, the Protocol and the Final Act. All of the conditions have therefore been met for Croatia to accede to the European Union from 1 January 2013, becoming its 28th Member State. This is a very long process, the final stages of which have only been possible due to the determination of all the politicians involved and a consistent EU policy. Only through this process have there been significant steps taken in the relations between Croatia and Serbia. However, this process does not end on 9 December with the signing of the Treaty of Accession in Brussels. Although much has been done, particularly in terms of combating corruption, much remains still to do, especially in relation to human rights, the consolidation of the Rule of Law and the fulfilment of all the criteria of the Copenhagen Agreement. I am therefore voting for this report and I welcome the way in which this process has been conducted, as it sets an example for other candidate countries for accession to the EU to follow.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: We believe that the decision on Croatia’s accession, or that of any other country, to the European Union must, first and foremost, come from the free expression of the sovereign will of this country’s people. Having said that, we should naturally neither ignore nor underestimate the meaning, nature and aims of this process of integration.

The report lists a range of obligations with which Croatia must comply. We are facing the unravelling of the arguments and the neoliberal blueprint upon which this EU keeps insisting. The rhetoric of sacrosanct free competition and ‘social market economy’, a euphemistic expression for the capitalist economy is, in fact, increasingly antisocial, as experience strongly bears out.

The EU cannot have a prosperous future if, as this report demonstrates, it regulates its every action in terms of enlargements and other structuring policies through multinationals’ access to markets and raw materials, imposing destructive policies on productive sectors and on employment. For all of these reasons, we abstained from voting.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: Twenty years after declaring independence, and almost eight years after applying for membership of the EU, Croatia has reached an historic milestone, with the successful completion of the accession talks and the country now in the process of joining the EU, and these successes deserve unconditional acknowledgement. The accession process is making a substantial contribution to Croatia’s transformation into a solid and mature democratic country whose membership can strengthen the Union, enrich its European culture and heritage and make a major contribution to preserving the credibility of the expansion process. Despite considerable progress, however, I firmly believe that it is important to continue with the reforms initiated, that it is necessary to focus particularly on commitments undertaken in the area of the judiciary, internal affairs and basic rights – including the protection of media freedom, the impartial resolution of war crimes cases, the fight against corruption, protection of minorities, border controls, police cooperation, the fight against organised crime and judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters – as well as on commitments undertaken in the area of competition policy. Croatia’s determination to combat corruption, and also the progress achieved in the area of women’s rights and gender equality, for example, are pleasing. It is desirable for Croatia to continue consolidating good neighbourly relations, to continue as an important and active promoter of regional cooperation at all levels, and to back up its efforts towards membership with steps that will be economically, socially and generally beneficial to all citizens of this region.

intervention.name: Pat the Cope GALLAGHER
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I fully support the accession of Croatia to the European Union. The next step is for the Member States and for Croatia to sign the Accession Treaty following a national referendum. It is thought that Croatia will accede to the EU on 1 July 2013.

intervention.name: Robert GOEBBELS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I abstained from voting on Croatia’s accession. Croatia is clearly a State destined to become a member of the European Union. However, this latest enlargement comes at the worst possible time. The Union’s budget is woeful. The financial perspective is heading towards further austerity. Moreover, and most importantly, the Union does not yet have the regulations necessary for it to function better and to take swifter decisions. The European commotion will only get worse if we move from 27 to 28 States.

intervention.name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The great tradition of European integration continues. Following the European Parliament’s vote in favour of Croatia’s accession, the EU is preparing to welcome its 28th member. By voting in favour, I wanted to show my support for the accession of a country whose history and culture, but also, and above all, its geography, make it European through and through. Not so long ago, the Balkans were entrenched in war. Since then, the countries of the former Yugoslavia have made rapid progress along the path of reform and integration. Of course, Croatia still has a long way to go before it meets EU standards, but with this vote, the European Parliament has just reaffirmed Zagreb’s EU aspirations.

intervention.name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the EU; the country should thus become the 28th member of the EU by 1 July 2013 at the latest. Clearly, between now and then, Croatia must continue its efforts to guarantee its membership. In recent years, Croatia has implemented reforms that have helped make its institutions more transparent and accountable. Despite the severity of the crisis, the country is investing in policies to create green jobs and undertaking ambitious reforms. This positive vote therefore serves to confirm the legitimacy of Croatia’s accession to the EU and rewards its efforts to date.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this document because accession negotiations with Croatia have now been concluded, bringing to an end almost six years of negotiation and several years of preparation that have significantly altered the country’s socio-political, economic and cultural landscape. Reforms must continue, however, and I believe that this process is not complete but should continue with the same vigour and hard work after the conclusion of the negotiations and beyond accession. The positive results of this process will strengthen support for EU membership among Croatia’s citizens, as well as their trust in it, and will encourage people to participate in the EU referendum and support the signing of the Accession Treaty. I welcome the signing of the Accession Treaty, and all EU Member States should now complete its ratification in a timely manner.

intervention.name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I support Croatia’s accession to the European Union and welcome the important steps which have been taken towards this. Hannes Swoboda’s report welcomes the conclusion of the accession negotiations and calls on Croatia to organise a referendum and vote on the Accession Treaty. It also calls on Member States to conclude the ratification process quickly. I supported this report. Croatia has met its commitments. However, the Croatian Government needs to resolve the challenges which persist, such as those posed by the judicial system and the continuing battle against corruption and organised crime. Structural reforms also need to be made in the economy, and competitiveness must be stimulated.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This report welcomes the conclusion of accession negotiations with Croatia. It also supports the country’s spirit of reform and calls on all players across the political, economic, social and cultural spectrum to embrace it. I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: Giovanni LA VIA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The adoption of this report brings an end to a journey that began six years ago and is hugely significant for both Croatia and the European Union. The enlargement of the EU to include Croatia represents an opportunity for growth and development for both parties to the agreement. This is an important moment and one that concludes years of negotiations that have seen Croatia striving to build social and economic standards in line with the EU’s expectations and principles. It must not be forgotten that the political history of Croatia, as well as many other countries in the Balkans, reflects a difficult and complex path of building democracy. I am sure that today, a new journey has begun which will see, on the one hand, Croatia committed to improving its social sectors and, on the other, the European Union strengthened by enlargement incorporating a new Member State, according to the principles set out by our founding fathers in the awareness of the importance of being united in diversity.

intervention.name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the EU. As a representative of a country featuring among the most recent Member States to have joined the European Union, I am pleased that yet another country is going to join the EU in 2013. Croatia’s accession offers a beginning and a model for all the countries in the Western Balkans. The European integration of the Western Balkans is a key strategy for achieving the European objectives of stability and prosperity. Croatia has made progress in every area involved in the accession process during the last 12 months and is a state offering great potential for the EU. The accession process has made a considerable contribution to turning Croatia into a democracy based on European values and has given impetus to the political and economic reforms. All these efforts from the Croatian State must be rewarded so that its citizens can enjoy fully their country’s status as an EU Member State.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the amendment expressing concerns about the treatment of people who took part in a LGBT pride march in Split on 11 June 2011.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I am voting in favour of the report by Mr Swoboda. The rapporteur has provided a timely reminder of the positive aspects of Croatia’s accession to the European Union and carefully set out the steps that Croatia will have to take in order to foster its European identity, both in its institutions and in the hearts and minds of its citizens.

intervention.name: Mairead McGUINNESS
intervention.p: This is a historical moment and I strongly support this report welcoming Croatian accession. I look forward to its expected entry into the EU on 1 July 2013, following the ratification process.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: The success of Croatia’s accession will have major implications at European level, boosting the process of European integration, as well as being a symbol of hope for the Balkans. Certainly, its accession to the EU provides a strong incentive for potential candidates for accession in that region to effect the political, legislative and economic reforms necessary, so that Croatia’s neighbouring countries fulfil the obligations inherent in the course of full accession to the EU.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: I did not vote in favour of this report because, although my group has always been in favour of Croatia joining the EU, just as it is of any other country that meets the established requirements, I cannot support the EU’s demand for Croatia to implement reforms that go against the interests of the Croatian people. Throughout the accession process, the EU’s main objective has been to foster a competitive neoliberal economy in Croatia and bring about privatisation in certain key sectors. The focus was on improving conditions to make Croatia more attractive to foreign investors. Thus, the reforms being encouraged by the EU are basically aimed at overhauling the socio-economic system, which will lead to increased social and economic differences in the country. That is why I abstained from voting on this report.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Croatia has been able to rely on the broad support of the other Member States throughout the accession process. Our neighbour has not failed to assert our shared values, which is a key consideration. By joining the EU in 2013, Croatia will strengthen its role and its contribution to the creation of a stable region in South-East Europe. I strongly urge our future 28th Member State to cooperate more with Serbia in judicial matters and in the pursuit of war criminals. Accession should also be an opportunity for Croatia to maintain bilateral relations with the other Balkan countries, thereby reaffirming its central position within that region.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour because I think that Croatia should continue stepping up the reforms, in particular, in the field of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and the integration of refugees. The completion of the accession talks and the start of the ratification of the Accession Treaty must not stop the reforms.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: Croatia’s application for membership of the European Union is very much to be welcomed. Having always worked to fulfil the tasks assigned by the EU since the start of accession negotiations, Croatia will be a reliable partner at European level. For this reason, we should welcome the closer integration of the Croatian people, who have always belonged to Europe in cultural terms. Unlike other accession candidates, such as Turkey for example, there is no doubt in relation to Croatia that accession is a logical step in European integration once all the criteria are met – provided that this is the wish of the Croatian people. For this reason, I have voted in favour of Croatia’s application for membership of the European Union.

intervention.name: Radvilė MORKŪNAITĖ-MIKULĖNIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The example of Croatia again shows that integration into the EU is one of the most effective methods of economic, political and even social change. EU enlargement requires much effort and commitment but is a mutually beneficial instrument which ensures peace, stability, reconciliation and development, and this effect is not confined to one country but also has a regional impact. I hope that Croatia’s success will encourage the other states in the region to go energetically down this path. Even after the Treaty concerning the Accession of the Republic of Croatia has been signed at the European Council on 8-9 December, it will not be a time for relaxation but rather for continuing political and economic reforms, in particular, in the areas of consolidating the rule of law, combating corruption and organised crime, safeguarding human rights, improving the business environment and creating friendly and stable relations with neighbours. The EU must also prepare properly for Croatia’s accession, take account of it in the 2013 multiannual financial framework, and include Croatia in negotiations for the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. I hope that the ratification process in EU countries will run smoothly and that Croatia will be ready to become the 28th Member State as scheduled from 1 July 2013, during the Lithuanian Council Presidency.

intervention.name: Kristiina OJULAND
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The green light by the European Parliament to the application of Croatia to accede to the EU comes at a very right time. When some external actors may wish to see the EU disintegrating, the accession of a new member sends out a reassuring signal: ‘The reports of its death are greatly exaggerated’. The accession of Croatia does not, however, mark the end of the country’s European integration. The experience of Estonia, as well as of the other Member States that have joined recently, has taught that even more difficult challenges lay ahead. It is far more demanding to establish a relatively small country as a full-fledged active Member State on a routine basis than to meet the fixed criteria and conclude the negotiations. Membership calls for a long-term perspective, patience and willingness to compromise for the common good in order to secure the viability of European Union as an influential global actor. I look forward to working with my future colleagues from Croatia to reach those goals and hope that soon enough, we may greet all the Western Balkans to the European Union.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcome this resolution on the accession of Croatia to the European Union. We should welcome the fact that finally, Croatia has successfully reached an historic milestone in the EU integration process. Accession negotiations with Croatia have now been concluded, bringing to an end almost six years of negotiation and several years of preparation. With the political, economic, social and cultural reforms that have been implemented, Croatia has become a solid and mature democracy. It should be borne in mind that accession to the EU should not be regarded as the end of a process but merely a step along the path of ongoing and continuous administrative and economic modernisation.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report as I am convinced that the enlargement of the EU is an inherent part of the European project which, with Croatia’s accession, should grow stronger. The conclusion of accession negotiations with Croatia puts an end to almost six years of negotiations and several years of preparation which have changed the socio-political, economic and cultural landscape of the country considerably. Accession to the EU will allow Croatia to maintain the pace of the reforms which it has embarked upon and link it to a project which, given its geographical location, cannot be anything other that its own.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: About eight years ago, Croatia applied to join the European Union. In the meantime, profound changes have taken place in the political situation of that country, leading to Croatia’s transformation into a solid democracy, underpinned by its respect for human rights, which deserves EU policy makers’ applause. Moreover, if we think about the European Union, Croatia’s accession represents the opening up of the Balkans and one more step towards uniting all of Europe politically. In this sense, an incentive for the consolidation of democracies of the different states of the Balkan Peninsula opens up here, with a view to possible accession to the common area. In view of these facts, it is necessary to begin the process of effective entry into the EU. As such, I voted for the resolution and I look forward to the Republic of Croatia’s accession, which represents another step forward in the history of the EU.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The EP has today given its broad support to Croatian membership, recognising the huge progress made towards reforms by Croatia. The process of reform is not over, however, and Croatia should continue on its reform path. This is particularly true in the areas of justice reform, anti-corruption reforms, minority protection and the prosecution of war crimes. The EP has today also criticised the crackdown on the last Gay Pride Parade in Split, in spite of efforts by the EPP to muzzle this criticism. The EP must now continue to monitor the situation to ensure Croatia implements all reforms and that the EU Commission properly oversees this. To this end, the Greens believe the EP should be given the role of assessing the 6-monthly monitoring reports on Croatia's progress. MEPs also have an important role to convince EU citizens that continuing the enlargement process in the Western Balkans is in the interest of all in Europe.

intervention.name: Licia RONZULLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this document advocating Croatia’s accession to the EU because I think that this country joining the European Union is of strategic importance. However, as pointed out in the document, it is important that the Croatian Government tackles the last remaining queries still pending, particularly in the field of judicial reform and fighting corruption and organised crime.

intervention.name: Tokia SAÏFI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In the last few years, Croatia, which has been in accession negotiations with the European Union since 2005, has implemented radical structural reforms enabling it to meet EU membership requirements. Major reforms have been carried out with a view to promoting job creation, increasing competitiveness and strengthening fiscal policies. Many challenges remain, and the Croatian authorities must continue their reforms, particularly their judicial reforms, to combat corruption and organised crime. In order to heal the wounds of the past, Croatia needs to redouble its efforts to prosecute war criminals, follow the set of recommendations made by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and encourage the return of war refugees, especially the Serbs. Croatia’s forthcoming accession is a positive signal for the region as a whole; it is a sign that reforms pay, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: Nikolaos SALAVRAKOS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: Political enlargement of the EU is one of the most basic parameters of European integration and the enlargement process, as applied by the EU, is also an instrument which provides the facility for constant monitoring of the progress being made by candidate countries, thereby acting as a force for political and economic reform in candidate countries. Enlargement policy is a basic instrument for regional cooperation and for maintaining good neighbourly relations. I wish Croatia every success in its accession endeavour and I trust that it will continue its reform efforts at the same pace.

intervention.name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: During the previous parliamentary term, I had the pleasure of working in the Delegation to the EU-Croatia Joint Parliamentary Committee. The accession of Croatia to the European Union means a strengthening of political stability in the Western Balkans. Let us hope that it is the beginning of the next enlargement of the EU, to include the countries that were formed on the territory of the former Yugoslavia.

I believe that Croatia has fulfilled the necessary economic and political criteria. This was undoubtedly very difficult, considering the situation in which the region finds itself, as new relations are currently forming during a period of crisis. The country would do well to keep up the rate of change, introduce the rule of law, fight corruption and prepare for the challenges of the common market. Welcome and good luck!

intervention.name: Sergio Paolo Francesco SILVESTRIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Croatia joining the European Union. As we wait for Croatian citizens to have their say in a referendum, the EU has given an initial green light to a Union of 28 countries. In the run-up to 1 July 2013, Croatia must continue to resolve its domestic problems, first and foremost fighting corruption and undertaking legal reforms. Structural reforms are needed to keep public debt under control and improve the labour market. So far, Croatia has complied with all the limits that were imposed, even in spite of the ongoing global economic crisis. This is, without doubt, a good sign which gives some hope that this Balkan country will be able to join the EU successfully.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Croatia’s accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013 will be the culmination of eight years of negotiations that deserve full recognition in view of Croatia’s transformation into a solid and mature democracy based on the integral values of the EU. This accession will act as a catalyst for the processes of reform in the Western Balkans. This event will allow Croatia and its citizens to enjoy the rights and guarantees enshrined in the EU Treaties. Along with their rights, the authorities must meet the commitments made during the negotiations and foster the participation of the representatives of civil society throughout the accession procedure. Alongside this, additional support through the Instrument of Pre-Accession Assistance should carry on and adapt to the efforts being made towards reform.

I am voting for this report and would stress that it is still necessary to continue with policies for the reform of the judicial system, so that it is impartial and transparent, for the fight against corruption and cross-border organised crime, and cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, especially through the prosecution of war crimes and the integration of refugees and displaced persons.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on Croatia’s application to become a member of the European Union because enlarging the EU through Croatia’s accession will help strengthen stability, freedom and prosperity in Europe. One of the EU’s objectives is to strengthen solidarity among its various peoples while respecting their history, culture and traditions. Croatia’s accession requires respect for the values on which the EU is based, as well as for the commitment to promote them. I welcome Croatia’s declaration on promoting European values in South-East Europe. The negotiations were completed on 30 June 2011, the provisions for which were agreed as being fair and appropriate. Consequently, Croatia fulfils the political criteria and we expect it to be ready to join on 1 July 2013. Croatia must continue the economic structural reforms, stimulate employment by revitalising the labour market and continue with fiscal consolidation to stimulate competitiveness. It is important that economic recovery is accompanied by environmental modernisation, including through improving energy efficiency, reinforcing policies on renewable energy sources and harmonising spatial development and energy policies. I urge Croatia to continue to strengthen the rights of workers and trade unions and to enhance social dialogue as part of the decision-making process.

intervention.name: Derek VAUGHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report in support of Croatia’s accession to the EU and I look forward to the signature of the Accession Treaty. During negotiations Croatia has worked hard to reform its judicial system, but there remains a need to ensure that progress continues to be made especially on issues such as anti-corruption and minority protection. It is vital that the European Parliament continues to monitor the pre-accession process and is kept informed by the European Commission of the steps taken by Croatia to honour the negotiation commitments.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The European Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the accession negotiations with Croatia, while also calling on the Republic to continue the initiated reforms with the same level of commitment – specifically in the areas of justice, cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and anti-discrimination policy. I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report as I support all measures that help to increase the credibility of politics and, in particular, to increase transparency and confidence in Parliament.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Since I am in favour of MEPs’ activities becoming more transparent, I voted in favour of Carlo Casini’s report. This Code of Conduct aims to make MEPs more accountable by requiring them to declare the professional activities they undertake alongside their parliamentary duties as well as those they carried out before they took office. It also contains provisions relating to their parliamentary remuneration and all outside remuneration as well as penalties for violations of the Code.

intervention.name: Regina BASTOS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Parliament has approved changes relating to the Code of Conduct of its Members. These amendments aim to strengthen transparency in the fulfilment of their mandate and free vote. The Code of Conduct also provides for penalties in cases of a breach of the established rules that go as far as suspension or removal of their mandate in Parliament. The principles which should govern and guide the behaviour of those elected to Parliament are those of ethical and moral responsibility, as well as strict adherence to the mission of honourable representation that citizens confer upon them. I voted for this report for these reasons.

intervention.name: Jean-Luc BENNAHMIAS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: We all remember the scandal of the MEPs who ‘sold’ amendments to false lobbyists who were, in fact, journalists. Although this case, which illustrates the general climate of suspicion towards the political class, only involved a tiny minority of MEPs, it sowed doubt about Members’ integrity. By establishing strict rules governing the declaration of financial interests and the prevention of conflicts of interest, the Code of Conduct aims to improve transparency and therefore, so I hope, the image of MEPs in the eyes of the outside world. MEPs will have to declare the professional activities they undertake alongside their parliamentary duties as well as those they carried out before they took office, and rapporteurs may see themselves relieved of that role if a conflict of interest is brought to light. The point of the Code of Conduct is to restore accountability. It is about ensuring that cases like this, which harm everyone, do not happen again in the future.

intervention.name: Mara BIZZOTTO
intervention.p: The report sets out a series of laudable amendments to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament. The importance of our roles here means that we are duty-bound, both politically and in terms of ethics and transparency, to make the rules governing the relationship between our positions and our outside interests as stringent and rigorous as possible. I support the insertion of these amendments as per the report by Mr Casini, especially the introduction of greater clarity on conflicts of interest and the funding and support received for carrying out our political activities. The new provisions on penalties for breaching the code and the creation of an Advisory Committee on the behaviour of MEPs are also to be welcomed. My vote on the report by Mr Casini is therefore in favour.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this report on the amendments to the Rules of Procedure relating to a Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest, as it introduces rigorous amendments to the Code of Conduct, which should contribute towards greater transparency and confidence in Parliament.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: It is very important that Members of Parliament fulfil their mandates in fully independent and absolutely transparent conditions. It is, therefore, necessary to welcome the adoption of a Code of Conduct that aims to safeguard independence, transparency and avoid conflicts of interest, similar to what is happening in numerous other areas of activity, especially in other professions that have their own codes of ethics that impose a healthy self-regulation.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: The report in question, drafted by Mr Casini, deals with the amendments to Parliament’s Rules of Procedure relating to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest. The current economic crisis, which many citizens attribute to politicians’ wrong decisions, has led to this group of professionals being put under very tight public surveillance involving new information technology, as in the case of Wikileaks , with the disclosure of confidential information. Today, more than ever before, it is crucial that rules for transparency are established with respect to the financial interests of public officials. In the case of Members of the European Parliament, under the terms of Article 232 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it is up to Parliament to establish rules on the interests of its Members. As I am aware that appearances are extremely important, I am voting for the proposed amendments to the existing regulation.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: Broadly speaking, the report considers that the new Code of Conduct will increase the transparency needed for elected Members of the European Parliament (EP) to perform their duties. The Members of the EP will have to submit a declaration of financial interests containing a range of information including, inter alia , their employment history for the three-year period before taking office with the EP. This report follows some scandals involving Members of the current legislative term, some of whom have since resigned, hence the concerns that are now being mentioned here.

Naturally, we agree with the ban on accepting or receiving ‘any direct or indirect financial benefit or other reward in exchange for influencing, or voting on, legislation, motions for a resolution, written declarations or questions tabled in Parliament or any of its committees’. The Code of Conduct stipulates that Members cannot enter into ‘any agreement to act or vote in the interest of any other legal or natural that would compromise their freedom of vote’. Its effectiveness will need to be assessed and monitored.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: The report states that the new Code of Conduct aims to increase transparency. Members of the European Parliament (EP) will have to submit a declaration of financial interests containing a range of information including, inter alia , their employment history for the three-year period before taking up office with the EP, and their membership during that period of any boards or committees of companies, etc. Any occasional remunerated outside activity, including writing, lecturing or the provision of expert advice, must also be declared if the total remuneration exceeds EUR 5 000 in a calendar year.

We know that this report appeared following some scandals involving certain Members that have already left Parliament, hence the concerns that are now being mentioned here. For example, the Code of Conduct stipulates that Members cannot enter into ‘any agreement to act or vote in the interest of any other legal or natural that would compromise their freedom of vote’ or ‘accept or receive any direct or indirect financial benefit or other reward in exchange for influencing, or voting on, legislation, motions for a resolution, written declarations or questions tabled in Parliament or any of its committees’. We shall see how effective it is.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: The changes to the Rules of Procedure will introduce new, clearer and more precise rules and a stricter sanctions regime, which should increase confidence in the European Parliament, and contribute to transparency in EU institutions. The changes to the rules will come mainly in the following areas: the introduction of stricter rules and greater transparency in an effort to prevent conflicts of interest, clear rules regarding the financial statements that will be available on the website of the European Parliament, and stricter rules on donations and similar benefits. The possibility of removing the mandate of a rapporteur in the event of a serious violation of the Code of Conduct is also significant.

intervention.name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER de OEDENBERG
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I would like to express my full support for the contents of the new Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest. I am glad that we managed to reach a compromise during work in the relevant committee, as reflected by the large number of votes cast by my fellow Members in favour of amending the Rules of Procedure. New changes to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament represent yet another important step towards introducing clearer rules and, at the same time, clear sanctions for a failure to comply with these rules, and they aim to increase confidence in Parliament as well as making the work of the European institutions more transparent overall.

The new rules focus on introducing rigorous provisions in relation to the problem of conflicts of interest, the preparation of financial statements published on Parliament’s website and the acceptance of special gifts. Moreover, the new provisions also cover rapporteurs, who may lose their mandate if they violate the abovementioned rules contained in the Code of Conduct. I think that the creation of an Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members is also a good initiative, which will assist Members in the practical interpretation and implementation of the rules of the code. I would once again like to thank the rapporteur from the Committee on Constitutional Affairs for the huge amount of work he has put into preparing the report.

intervention.name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I voted in favour of establishing this new Code of Conduct for MEPs. The code forbids Members from undertaking lobbying activities alongside their parliamentary duties, prohibits us from receiving gifts worth more than EUR 150, requires us to notify all the activities that we carry out and remuneration that we receive whilst we are MEPs and before we take office, and requires us to declare any membership of an association, any type of interest in a company or organisation of so-called ‘influence’ and any other type of financial interest. In particular, I voted in favour of Amendment 10, which proposed abolishing the EUR 5 000 threshold above which MEPs must declare all outside activities for which they receive payment. By establishing these strict rules, our Parliament intends to make its daily activities clearer and more transparent. Equally, this is about restoring, to some extent, the external image of MEPs and about combating the prevailing anti-parliamentarism. This code is also intended to re-establish everyone’s accountability. I regret, however, that such measures are only adopted in response to scandals (one recalls here the scandal of the three MEPs caught acting in a blatantly corrupt manner by lobbyists in March 2011).

intervention.name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
intervention.p: I supported the creation of an enhanced Code of Conduct for MEPs in order to provide a clear signal regarding my demands for elected officials to act transparently and to abide by a number of ethical rules. Accordingly, I consider it essential to prevent Members from undertaking an additional professional activity involving lobbying activities that could have an improper influence on the performance of their duties. Further, in order to rule out any possible abuse, provision must be made for penalties, which are proposed in this Code of Conduct. Finally, I rejected the initiatives aimed at weakening this set of measures – which some felt were ‘too transparent’ – as they would have prevented us from achieving an objective: that of restoring citizens’ faith in their elected officials.

intervention.name: Marian HARKIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I support this report as it goes a long way towards putting in place a Code of Conduct for MEPs in regard to financial interests and conflicts of interest. It is important that we carry out work in the most transparent way and, indeed, in an accountable fashion. However, I supported the amendment which proposed that we declare any remunerated income, not only that above EUR 5 000. I know there are administrative issues but this figure is far too high. For some people in some Member States, EUR 5 000 represents a year’s income and regardless of where you live, it is a very significant sum of money. I am concerned that we are giving out the wrong message here, and much of the good work we do will have been cancelled out by leaving this EUR 5 000 figure as part of the Code of Conduct – it is just too high.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I welcomed the amendments to the Rules of Procedure introducing a requirement to declare any other paid activity and income. It is my conviction that, in exercising their duties, Members of the European Parliament should be guided by and observe the following general principles of conduct: unselfishness, integrity, openness, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect for Parliament’s reputation. They should therefore act solely in the public interest and refrain from obtaining or seeking to obtain any direct or indirect financial benefit or other reward.

intervention.name: Petru Constantin LUHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I welcome the adoption of the Code of Conduct for MEPs as there was a great need for such a code. The Code of Conduct defines conflicts of interest and envisages the option to sanction MEPs, including by suspension or removal from office. The code clearly indicates that MEPs cannot accept money or benefits in exchange for votes or legislative or political activities within the European Parliament. In addition, according to the new code, MEPs must submit a declaration of financial interests which specifies some of the following details: - professional activities from the last three years prior to taking up office in Parliament; - any regular remunerated activity carried out as an MEP, alongside the exercise of their office; - any occasional remunerated outside activity (including writing, lecturing or the provision of expert advice) if the total remuneration exceeds EUR 5 000 in a calendar year; - any gift or benefit valued at more than EUR 150, received by an MEP when carrying out his or her duties, must be refused or, if officially representing Parliament, be transferred to the European Parliament.

intervention.name: Monica MACOVEI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this first Code of Conduct for MEPs. The code defines the conflict of interest, requires the disclosure of activities during the three years prior to the MEP’s mandate, and foresees the possibility to apply penalties, including the suspension or removal of the MEP from office. The code is a first step towards transparency and the prevailing of public interest. The code shows clearly that MEPs cannot receive money or favours in exchange for their vote or their legislative or political activity with the European Parliament. We should go further and prohibit paid membership of boards of directors, as well as a second paid job, except teaching and similar work clearly defined.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am delighted that the European Parliament has adopted a code of conduct which compares with the best practice in any of our national parliaments.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: Recent events involving certain Members of the European Parliament, which led to the resignation of a number of them, have forced Parliament to adopt some changes to the Code of Conduct of its Members. They are seeking to increase transparency in the performance of their duties and in their freedom of vote. These changes also provide for penalties in the event of non-compliance with the rules that have been laid down, which could result in the suspension or removal of a Member. There are certain principles that must be upheld in the conduct of those elected to Parliament when performing the duties for which they were elected by the people of their respective countries: these are to fulfil an ethical and moral responsibility and to scrupulously carry out the mandate granted by the electorate, which is to represent the people honourably. That is why I voted as I did.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report because it represents progress in the fight against nepotism and corruption in Parliament. We must learn from our mistakes and make sure the regulation is reviewed in two years’ time. The new regulation contains stricter rules on donations and declarations of interests and income, but we must continue to call for even stricter standards.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Amendments are aimed at making the financial side of MEPs’ work become more clear and transparent.

intervention.name: Radvilė MORKŪNAITĖ-MIKULĖNIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Although the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged legislative institution under the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular, as regards establishing the EU budget, the media and voters probably talk more about our salaries, benefits and related scandals than about the work we do. It is also a fact that Members of the European Parliament are able to obtain any amount of remuneration or other income from other sources without having to declare or report it to anybody.
