MEPs’ salaries are several or even many times greater than those of many of their constituents, so that when we talk about reducing poverty in Europe one day and then oppose a requirement to declare additional income the next, we look hypocritical. I welcome the amendments to the Rules of Procedure introducing a requirement to declare any other paid activity and income. It is nevertheless important that these provisions are actually implemented and do not remain merely aspirational. On the other hand, I believe that we could go even further by prohibiting MEPs from receiving any additional remuneration, as is done in some Member States’ national parliaments. Surely we will not become impoverished by living solely from our salary?

intervention.name: Franz OBERMAYR
intervention.p: The present crisis of confidence underlines the need for a clear code of conduct for Members of the European Parliament in relation to financial interests and possible conflicts of interest. Every MEP should perform his or her duties in accordance with the fundamental principles of impartiality, integrity, openness, due diligence, honesty, responsibility and maintaining Parliament’s good name. When a conflict of interest arises, the provisions of this code of conduct should provide some guidance. If the MEP is unable to resolve the conflict of interest, he is obliged to inform the President in writing. In cases of doubt, confidential advice can be sought from the Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members. In addition, before speaking or voting in plenary or at any of Parliament’s institutions, or when proposed as rapporteur, every Member should disclose any existing or potential conflict of interest in relation to the matter under consideration. Such a disclosure can be made orally or in writing to the President during the relevant parliamentary debates. I believe that these measures make sense and will promote confidence. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

intervention.name: Siiri OVIIR
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I consider it important to change the European Parliament’s Rules of Procedure, which would, among other things, create a better overview of Members’ paid extra-parliamentary activities and the income connected therewith. Although I support Mr Casini’s report, I do not support sub-clause ‘e’ of the motion to amend clause 2 number 10, which would require Members of Parliament to declare in their declarations of economic interests only those extra-parliamentary expenses above EUR 5 000 per calendar year. I find that the establishment of such a limit is not justified because it would encourage the non-declaration of income that falls just short of the EUR 5 000 limit. In addition, it is unclear why EUR 5 000 should be chosen as the limit; why not EUR 2 000 or 200, for instance? EUR 5 000 is a large amount of money – in many Member States, it represents the annual pay of a worker who earns average wages. I believe that in the interests of greater transparency, Members of the European Parliament should declare all income received from extra-parliamentary activities, and if we are to set a limit, it could be 10 times lower, for instance, EUR 500.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Clarity and transparency are at the heart of the work of all MEPs, since we are the direct representatives of our citizens’ interests. All of us, from our lofty positions, must set an example and not fall prey to compromises that contradict the goals of our mandates. The report by Mr Casini amends the regulation on the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament, adding yet further details, in the hope that nobody can fall foul any longer of financial irregularities and conflicts of interest. My vote in favour is tantamount to a personal promise to the electorate of clarity and transparency.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for the change to the Rules of Procedure regarding the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in respect of financial interests and conflicts of interest because I believe that it is a good draft overall. However, I believe that it could, and should, have gone further on certain points so as to increase transparency, not least as regards the salaries of Members, which should be made public without exception. That is what I have advocated and continue to advocate along with other fellow Members who have also been defeated in this battle.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: The Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest aims to equip the EU’s legal system with instruments that will ensure transparency in decision-making procedures, so as to prevent situations of abuse of power. However, in order for these rules to come into effect, the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament must be amended. That is the aim of the current proposal, which is why I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Frédérique RIES
intervention.p: The Code of Conduct for MEPs adopted this afternoon responds to the need for our day-to-day work in the European Parliament to become clearer and more transparent. Equally, it responds to the recent scandals caused by a few MEPs who were paid to defend particular interests, unspeakable behaviour that was immediately denounced by the Presidency of Parliament and the national and European parties who rushed to exclude these black sheep. The new rules include greater transparency and control over Members’ declarations of financial interests, a clear definition of the meaning of conflict of interest, the obligation to refuse any gift worth more than EUR 150 and the establishment of a committee in which Members are monitored by their peers. Be that as it may, and to quote a colleague who has a way with words: ‘Catching someone with their hand in the cookie jar is no reason to ban cookies …’ Even with the strictest possible rules and penalties, you will not prevent abuse. Integrity is not decreed, it is applied, and it relies, above all, upon moral duty, personal ethics and a sense of responsibility, all values that do not bear compromise.

intervention.name: Robert ROCHEFORT
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: In any democratic society, citizens have the right to demand honest and responsible behaviour from their leaders. The legitimacy of power is at stake, and we cannot permit scandals involving a small number of politicians to affect the reputation of all decision makers. All conflicts of interest should therefore be avoided, and transparency must be the order of the day. Accordingly, all relevant information relating to the professional lives of Members should be made available to the public. In this respect, I welcome the vote on Carlo Casini’s report. The text aims, in fact, to make entirely worthy changes to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament with respect to financial interests and conflicts of interest: a reminder of the general principles of conduct – disinterest, integrity, openness, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect for Parliament’s reputation; the ability to suspend a Member from all of his or her duties or as rapporteur for a committee; the declaration of all offices that could influence parliamentary work and/or that are remunerated; the publication of financial support and support in terms of staff; and the supervision of courtesy gifts.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour, although I also supported the request to eliminate the EUR 5 000 threshold for declaring occasional remunerated activity. In my view, we have to declare everything, not only the income above EUR 5 000.

intervention.name: Licia RONZULLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this document because I believe that this code sets out rules and principles that MEPs ought to respect in their external dealings so as to avoid any conflicts of interest. The new Code of Conduct will offer a robust shield against unethical actions and is a big step forward in comparison to the current situation. The broad consensus shown by my fellow Members on the new Code of Conduct has a symbolic value that cannot be ignored. Externally, it shows the public that Parliament is a transparent mechanism working for the common good and for building Europe on the foundations of freedom and justice.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the European Parliament decision amending the Rules of Procedure regarding the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in respect of financial interests and conflicts of interest, as I think that Parliament needs to have clear regulations on transparency with regard to financial interests and the conduct of its members. The Rules of Procedure set out guidelines on how MEPs should exercise their office. In exercising their office, MEPs act only in the general interest without obtaining or trying to obtain any direct or indirect financial benefit or any other benefit. At the same time, MEPs are guided by and observe the following general principles of conduct: disinterest, integrity, transparency, diligence, honesty, accountability and respect for Parliament’s reputation. Parliament drafts rules on transparency with regard to the financial interests of its members in the form of a code of conduct, adopted by the majority of members who comprise it, in accordance with Article 232 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which will be appended to the Rules of Procedure. The Bureau adopts implementing measures for this Code of Conduct, including a monitoring procedure, and may submit proposals for revision of the Code of Conduct.

intervention.name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: I voted for this report, which clarifies and strengthens control over the money received by MEPs and what they do with it. This report is far from being the most fundamentally political of reports. It does, however, serve as a response to those who are attempting, once again, to win votes on the dangerous ground of anti-parliamentarism. To those people, who include certain members of the far right, we say: ‘There should be nothing to hide!’ Incidentally, I regret that the members of the Confederal Group of the European United Left – Nordic Green Left were the only ones who all voted against an amendment proposing to limit the declaration of supplementary income to income in excess of EUR 5 000. Unfortunately, this amendment was still adopted. Let us hope that this text will help put an end to numerous fantasies that discredit political action as a whole and that are constantly fed by the practices, inherent in human nature, of a few. Following this further step in the direction of greater transparency, political debate should refocus on far more important issues.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: This report deals with a number of amendments to the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in relation to financial interests and possible conflicts of interest in exercising their mandate. In line with the principle of transparency, in future, MEPs are to disclose their professional activities for the three years preceding their mandate, listing income – including non-regular income – and professional positions. I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report because the rapporteur argues cogently that the immunity of Mr Uspaskich cannot be defended.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: Following the criminal proceedings brought against a Member of this House, Mr Uspaskich, and pending before Vilnius Regional Court (Lithuania), Parliament decided on 7 September 2010 to waive his parliamentary immunity. Mr Uspaskich was unhappy with this decision and submitted two appeals. The first was submitted on 5 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 9 May 2011. The second was submitted on 11 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 4 July 2011. Since the two requests were related to the same matter, Parliament decided that they should be dealt with together. This report concerns Mr Uspaskich’s appeal of 5 April 2011 for Parliament to accede to his request to defend his immunity, in accordance with Article 7 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. Given that the incidents took place before he was elected to Parliament, and in view of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I am voting for Parliament’s decision not to defend Mr Uspaskich’s parliamentary immunity and privileges.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: It is appropriate to deal with the requests made by Viktor Uspaskich on 5 and 11 April 2011 together since they relate to the same legal proceedings. Criminal proceedings have been brought against the Member of the European Parliament (MEP), who is charged essentially with offences of false accounting in relation to the financing of a political party during a period prior to his election to the European Parliament. On 7 September 2010, Parliament waived Viktor Uspaskich’s immunity, considering that no cogent evidence had been furnished as to the existence of any fumus persecutionis and that the offences with which the MEP is charged had nothing to do with his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. Subsequently, on 28 October 2010, Viktor Uspaskich brought an action for the annulment of Parliament’s decision of 7 September 2010 before the General Court, only to withdraw it in July 2011. In a letter of 5 April 2011 requesting the defence of his immunity, he claims that the criminal proceedings initiated by the Lithuanian authorities prevent him from performing, or make it difficult for him to perform, his parliamentary duties by restraining his freedom of movement contrary to Article 7 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. After thoroughly examining all of the available facts, however, Parliament has concluded not to defend the immunity and privileges of Viktor Uspaskich and will forward this decision and the report of its competent committee to the appropriate authority in the Republic of Lithuania.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I followed the recommendation of the rapporteur in the case of Mr Viktor Uspaskich.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: It is Parliament’s responsibility to defend the independence of its Members’ mandates and that independence cannot be jeopardised. The Member of the European Parliament, Mr Uspaskich, is facing charges of offences of what is essentially false accounting in relation to the financing of a political party during a period prior to his election to the European Parliament. On 7 September 2010, Parliament waived the parliamentary immunity of Mr Uspaskich because it believed no convincing evidence had been given for his allegation of fumus persecutionis and that the criminal activities of which Mr Uspaskich is accused are unrelated to his activities as a Member of this House. That is why I am voting in favour of not waiving the parliamentary immunity and privileges of Mr Uspaskich.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I abstained from voting because the case is entirely political and not all aspects and documents of this case were carefully examined.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The JURI Committee has decided that Uspaskich’s claim should be rejected on the grounds that no sufficient nexus has been established between the alleged new facts and the bringing of proceedings against Uspaskich for false accounting.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report because the rapporteur argues cogently that the immunity of Mr Uspaskich cannot be defended.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: Following the criminal proceedings brought against a Member of this House, Mr Uspaskich, and pending before Vilnius Regional Court (Lithuania), Parliament decided on 7 September 2010 to waive his parliamentary immunity. Mr Uspaskich was unhappy with this decision and submitted two appeals. The first was submitted on 5 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 9 May 2011. The second was submitted on 11 April 2011 and was announced in Parliament in the plenary session of 4 July 2011. Since the two requests were related to the same matter, Parliament decided that they should be dealt with together. This report concerns Mr Uspaskich’s request to Parliament of 11 April 2011 to review the decision it made in the plenary session of 7 September 2010 to waive his parliamentary immunity. In view of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I am voting for Parliament’s decision not to defend the parliamentary immunity and privileges of Mr Uspaskich, given that the incidents took place before he was elected to Parliament and are unrelated to his duties as a Member of this House.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: It is appropriate to deal with the requests made by Viktor Uspaskich on 5 and 11 April 2011 together since they relate to the same legal proceedings. Criminal proceedings have been brought against the Member of the European Parliament (MEP), who is charged essentially with offences of false accounting in relation to the financing of a political party during a period prior to his election to the European Parliament. On 7 September 2010 Parliament waived Viktor Uspaskich’s immunity, considering that no cogent evidence had been furnished as to the existence of any fumus persecutionis and that the offences with which the MEP is charged had nothing to do with his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. Subsequently, on 28 October 2010, Viktor Uspaskich brought an action for the annulment of Parliament’s decision of 7 September 2010 before the General Court, only to withdraw it in July 2011. In a letter of 5 April 2011 requesting the defence of his immunity, he claims that the criminal proceedings initiated by the Lithuanian authorities prevent him from performing, or make it difficult for him to perform, his parliamentary duties by restraining his freedom of movement contrary to Article 7 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. After thoroughly examining all of the available facts, however, Parliament has concluded not to defend the immunity and privileges of Viktor Uspaskich and will forward this decision and the report of its competent committee to the appropriate authority in the Republic of Lithuania.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I abstained from voting because the case is entirely political and not all aspects and documents of this case were carefully examined.

intervention.name: Siiri OVIIR
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Unlike the other members of my group, I did not vote in favour of this report, which did not support the request by the Member of the European Parliament, Mr Viktor Uspaskich, who was elected from Lithuania, for a review of the European Parliament decision of 7 September 2010 regarding him. Through WikiLeaks, my earlier suspicion that the accusations made against Mr Uspaskich were politically motivated, and that procedure was violated in his case, were once again confirmed. Many Lithuanian politicians, including members of the governing party, have admitted that several procedural rules were violated, and that the accusations do not necessarily have any legal basis, but the withdrawal of the accusations made against Mr Uspaskich would tarnish the reputation of Lithuania’s governmental institutions and legal system. All of this reminds me of a series of earlier cases connected with members of my home party, the Estonian Centre Party, where it became clear after the elections that the accusations had been politically motivated and unfounded. In this case, protecting the reputation of the Lithuanian government agencies and legal system is not my concern, but the defence of justice and human rights is. These are among the axioms of the European Union considered to be of the utmost importance.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The European Parliament has been asked to waive the parliamentary immunity of a Member of this House, Mr Uspaskich. The Committee on Legal Affairs has issued its opinion on the matter, with a report that decided to waive his parliamentary immunity being adopted unanimously. Indeed, it was thought that no basis had been found for the allegation of fumus persecutionis in the case at hand.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The JURI Committee has decided that Uspaskich’s claim should be rejected on the grounds that no sufficient nexus has been established between the alleged new facts and the bringing of proceedings against Uspaskich for false accounting.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report because the rapporteur has tabled at least two important proposals: to reinforce Parliament’s role in the codecision process as regards the European Semester and to step up cooperation between Parliament and national parliaments.

intervention.name: Roberta ANGELILLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: We find ourselves in a specific moment of crisis in which the coordination of Member States’ economic policies has a crucial role. The experience of the preceding European Semester has shown that national reform programmes still lack transparency and viability. National economic and budgetary policies must be used to reach the objectives set out in the Stability Pact and the Europe 2020 strategy. That is why we need to assess the situation at a European level, so that the Union can take a coordinated approach in order to tackle European and national economic difficulties. I hope that in January, starting with the presentation of the Annual Growth Survey by the Commission, a clearer framework of all the future coordination actions in the economic sphere is mapped out for us, so that the challenges ahead can be faced with greater determination and fortitude.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The European Parliament demonstrated resolve and ambition in dealing with the economic and financial crisis when, last September, it adopted the ‘economic governance package’, which contains six legislative proposals all designed to strengthen economic governance in the European Union. One of these proposals includes the establishment of a European Semester, a forum for debate in which to assess and coordinate the economic and budgetary policies of Member States before they go ahead and adopt them. Although I am convinced that this coordination is essential in order to pull Europe out of the crisis, I note that the Berès report does not really heed the lessons of the first European Semester, trialled last July.

intervention.name: Margrete AUKEN
intervention.p: Paragraph 63 of the Berès report on the European Semester calls for ‘the development of the concept of a European Treasury to strengthen the implementation capacity of the European Semester and the economic pillar of EMU’. However, it is not explained in any more detail in the report what this concept of a European Treasury would cover. The members of the Danish Socialist People’s Party in the European Parliament therefore have reservations about this passage, but have voted in favour of the report in general, as it contains many good elements.

intervention.name: Jean-Luc BENNAHMIAS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The Berès report is commendable in that it rebalances the Commission’s proposal on the European Semester, which simply had to be done. By focusing on the priority of employment and on the idea that the budgetary, economic and social strategies introduced must have a redistributive and developmental role, the report gives new meaning to the prospects of overcoming the crisis, as we hope to do. Unfortunately, the European Parliament is still not involved enough in the European Semester process, just as, in fact, it is often excluded from the current crisis management efforts, which is a key problem for EU democracy and legitimacy. Therefore, I can only share the view that an interparliamentary conference involving both the EP and the national parliaments should be organised next year, so that, finally, we can open a broader debate on the measures we want to take and the project we want to support.

intervention.name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
intervention.p: I support this resolution because I think that coordination of economic policies is particularly important to the euro area’s operation, and this resolution contains a number of very useful recommendations for improving the European Semester. I think that the coordination process needs to have broader democratic legitimacy. For this to happen, the European Parliament and national parliaments need to be more actively involved. I am pleased that the rapporteur abandoned the notion of setting up a special parliamentary committee made up only of MEPs from the countries in the euro area, as such an initiative would have led to a split in Parliament, exerting an adverse impact on its operation. Such a measure is especially difficult to understand as most Member States which are not part of the euro area at the moment, including Romania, would like to adopt the single currency in the future. This means that all the Members of this Parliament have an interest in making the euro area operate efficiently. Last but not least, as is also recommended in this report, I feel it is absolutely essential that Member States’ economic policies attach major importance to economic growth as, in the current climate of austerity, we greatly need policies which will bring us back to the path of economic growth and put an end to austerity.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: The national parliaments are freely elected and are therefore the representatives and the guarantors of the rights acquired and delegated by the citizens. The introduction of the European Semester should fully respect the prerogatives of national parliaments. I welcome the introduction of the European Semester as an institutional process under the leadership of the EU institutions. I also welcome increased coordination among the Member States for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy, not least its macro-economic dimension.

intervention.name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: The European Semester and closer coordination of fiscal policies between the Member States, based on the prevailing neoliberal approach, is fully in keeping with plans by the Merkel/Sarkozy alliance. On the pretext of ‘regaining’ the trust of the markets, citizens’ rights are being sacrificed and social acquis is being trampled underfoot. Continuous austerity and continuous recession, unemployment and poverty are essentially becoming systemic. The European Semester has been overtaken by events. It no longer suffices to safeguard the interests of Ms Merkel and her allies. However, it is the ‘basic idea’ for creating a stricter stability pact and a ‘fiscal union of the willing’ which will put a stranglehold on the Member States and the European people. The budgets of the Member States will be planned and approved by Berlin, while the creation of a multi-track Europe of the ‘strong’ and the ‘weak’ will leave the weaker Member States prey to the whims of speculators. The report on the European Semester is fully in line with the failed neoliberal policies of the EU and deprives the Member States of the facility to exercise an alternative, anti-cyclical policy designed to redistribute wealth and sustainable growth. It is for all these reasons that I voted against the report.

intervention.name: Lara COMI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report since I believe that coordinating economic policies has an extremely important role to play in this period of major crisis for the European Union. Now more than ever, Europe must take a symmetrical approach, founded on a shared response from the Member States, to the problems deriving from the economic crisis, the resulting increase in inequality and macro-financial imbalances. In my opinion, the various countries’ policies ought to be highly interconnected so as to guarantee sustainable growth and increased employment, as set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The Union must address European citizens’ lack of faith in European integration. I therefore consider it essential that this coordination is geared towards ensuring greater legitimacy, accountability and transparency in decision-making processes. Furthermore, since the goal of the European Semester is to check that the budget discipline is being applied and to supervise the realisation of the EU 2020 strategy, the requirement for transparency is essential. I am hoping for greater effort from the Member States to ensure that economic, financial and social policies are more effective.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination because it highlights the need to step up the parliamentary dimension of economic governance by introducing the codecision process of the European Semester and strengthening cooperation between the national parliaments and the European Parliament.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Today, the European Semester is fully accepted as a cornerstone of the new economic governance framework. The main purpose of this process, which was set out for the first time in the first economic governance package, is to increase economic and fiscal coordination and to ensure the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy in all Member States. As such, it aims to attribute a greater level of democratic responsibility to national parliaments, in both the preparation and the subsequent implementation of their national budgets, and, at the same time, to offer a platform for the exchange of information and for sharing best budgetary implementation practices. It is undeniable that reinforcing economic coordination policies is one way for Europe to achieve the necessary fiscal consolidation it requires. The economic situation we are currently experiencing has further emphasised this need, and a lot certainly remains to be done in this respect.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: This report, drafted by Ms Honeyball, addresses the problem of early school leaving and the measures and instruments adopted by the EU aimed at assisting the Member States in setting out more efficient and effective national policies to resolve this problem. In the Europe 2020 strategy, the six headline targets include the reduction of the proportion of early school leavers to 10%. It should be noted that in 2009, the early school leaving rate for all 18 to 24-year-olds stood at 14.4%. This is a matter of extreme importance, as by tackling this problem, we will not only boost the self-esteem of citizens, but also improve their quality of life, thus helping to reduce poverty and the number of those who are socially excluded. Firstly, it is necessary to identify groups that are at risk, such as ethnic minorities, parents who have a low level of education, children from rural areas, as well as the causes of dropping out of school, such as academic failure and the factors that exacerbate it, including poverty, abuse and an unstable family background. In view of the fact that this problem requires a comprehensive approach and the mobilisation of all those involved in the process of education and teaching, I voted for this report.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: This is yet another crucial report because of the importance of the issues at stake and its profoundly negative implications. Like the other fundamental steps being taken in this process of European integration – which is clearly culminating in the serious economic and social crisis we are facing – this is yet another report that has the support of the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) and of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament. This unholy alliance is now trying to impose an ever greater budgetary discipline on the Member States. By making policy coordination an end in itself, it is seeking to gloss over the profoundly negative and reactionary nature of these policies.

Regrettably, the series of amendments we tabled to this report were not adopted, as they were rejected by the unholy alliance. For example, some of the amendments we tabled criticise the veritably aggressive programmes of the troika of the International Monetary Fund, the European Commission and the European Central Bank; defend a policy of effective budgetary stabilisation that takes account of growth and is aimed at wealth redistribution, sustainable development, job creation and social progress; and stress the need to reverse neoliberal economic policies in order to overcome the crisis. That is why we voted against.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: Imposing ever-increasing budgetary discipline on the Member States in line with the predominant economic policies will not help us to recover from this crisis or prevent a future crisis from breaking out. Instead, it may exacerbate its effects, increase inequality, poverty and unemployment, and lead to the impoverishment of the people.

We therefore tabled amendments to this report, which have not been adopted. For example, some of the amendments we tabled call on the Member States, the Council and the Commission to take account of the strong and ever-increasing resistance of European citizens to the harsh measures of the troika’s ‘bailout packages’ and the austerity policies followed; consider fiscal policy an important instrument in the management of economic and development policy, but the introduction of the European Semester and the stifling effects arising from the anticipation of fiscal policy coordination will prevent the Member States from having the ability and the flexibility required to pursue an effective stabilisation policy aimed at redistribution of wealth, at sustainable development and at job creation, so providing people with an adequate range of public services and infrastructure; and stress that trying to overcome the crisis by implementing stricter budgetary discipline and deregulation measures will not eliminate the root causes of the crisis but will instead aggravate the situation and reinforce neoliberal economic policies.
Regrettably, all of these have been rejected.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: The deepening crisis, inequalities and macro-financial imbalances and disparities in competitiveness have highlighted the need for the Union to tackle macro-economic imbalances more appropriately, coordinate economic and fiscal policies more closely, and improve budgetary surveillance. Several interlinked policies for sustainable growth and jobs should form the basis for an improved economic governance framework. Excessive debt and deficits in some Member States can have profound negative spill over effects on other Member States and on the euro area as a whole. I consider it necessary and important to ensure greater interaction between employment, social and economic policies in the context of the European Semester. These steps should be taken for the benefit of all generations and in a manner fostering democratic accountability, ownership and legitimacy of all actors involved. An essential part of this is the support and full involvement of the European Parliament. The European Semester is an institutional process, under the leadership of the European Union (EU) institutions, of increased coordination across Member States for the implementation of the EU strategy, notably in its macro-economic dimension.

intervention.name: Vicky FORD
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The ECR Group voted against the report on the basis that Article 121 of the TFEU clearly states that: ‘Member States shall regard their economic policies as a matter of common concern and shall coordinate them within the Council, in accordance with Article 120’. It is therefore against the TFEU for the report to call for a codecision procedure in paragraph 41. We also could not support paragraph 63 which calls for the development of the concept of a European Treasury. For these reasons, we were unable to support the report.

intervention.name: Estelle GRELIER
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for Ms Berès’s resolution as it is vitally important for the emergence of European economic governance to go hand in hand with greater democratic scrutiny. In order to deal with the major changes that will have to take place if it is to emerge from the crisis, the EU must ensure the strong democratic legitimacy of its decisions. This legitimacy can only be guaranteed with the European Parliament’s support and involvement in the annual drafting of the EU’s main economic policy guidelines. In particular, it is essential for Parliament to participate in the European Semester procedure, during which each of the 27 draft national budgets is assessed by the European Commission. Following this procedure, Parliament should have the chance to amend the macro-economic policy guidelines proposed to Member States. This democratic development also requires enhanced dialogue with the national parliaments and the social partners in order to support European economic policy coherence and guarantee that the EU 2020 objectives are taken into account. Finally, it is vital that the Treaties be revised only with the agreement and, where necessary, the involvement, of Parliament.

intervention.name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
intervention.p: I voted for Ms Berès’s report in order to denounce the current lack of democratic legitimacy regarding the definition of the Union’s economic framework, through the European Semester. The European Parliament and the national parliaments must be able to make their voices heard in this process so as to ensure its credibility. Indeed, a purely intergovernmental system of coordination is an inadequate response to the requirement for economic policies to be regarded as a matter of common concern. We must ensure only the requisite action by the Union in areas governed by the Community method. Lastly, the Annual Growth Survey must also be transformed into ‘Annual Sustainable Growth Guidelines’, aimed at enhancing sustainable growth, subject to a codecision procedure.

intervention.name: Gunnar Hökmark and Anna Ibrisagic
intervention.p: We Swedish Conservatives and Christian Democrats today voted in favour of an own-initiative report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The semester constitutes an important framework for increased budgetary discipline in the EU Member States. This report provides recommendations for how the current legislation should be updated, and we agree with most of the proposals. On the other hand, we are opposed to the recommendation to establish a ‘European Treasury’. We also believe that the semester should focus solely on factors that are essential for stable public finances.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: The European Semester is an institutional process, under the leadership of the EU institutions, of increased coordination across Member States for the implementation of EU strategy, notably in its macro-economic dimension. The European Semester has two objectives: to verify the application of budgetary discipline by Member States and – at the same time – to monitor the proper delivery of the Europe 2020 strategy by securing the financial means necessary for its implementation. I welcomed the document because the introduction of the European Semester should lead to the increased, well-defined involvement of the European Parliament and national parliaments and to changes in their work. The introduction of the European Semester and enhanced economic and fiscal policy coordination should leave enough scope and flexibility for the EU Member States to pursue an effective budgetary, economic and social strategy, appropriate in accordance with the EU 2020 strategy, geared to distribution and development and providing an adequate level of public services and infrastructure for EU citizens.

intervention.name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I supported the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination as I believe that stable export markets are in Latvia’s interests. Unfortunately, events in Europe no longer allow us to rely on the stability of these markets. We must therefore ensure that Member States, and the euro area countries in particular, agree on joint liability and put their national finances in order. Many euro area countries must now do as Latvia has successfully done in the last two years.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this resolution which ‘Views as regrettable the lack of clarity in, and the overlapping of, the different instruments and budgetary lines through which the Europe 2020 targets are to be achieved via the EU budget’ and ‘recalls that the European Semester provides a good opportunity to develop greater synergy between EU and Member State budgets’.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: As provided for in the Europe 2020 strategy, the improved economic governance framework should rely on several interlinked policies for sustainable growth and jobs, which need to be coherent with each other in order to provide sustainable growth and jobs. The European Semester offers a useful mechanism through which to put these proposals into action. The Member States in the euro area, which are linked by a shared responsibility, will, without doubt, benefit from it. My vote is in favour.

intervention.name: Arlene McCARTHY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Labour MEPs backed this lengthy report as it includes important and positive proposals, including the importance of the European Commission's analysis of growth focusing on long-term sustainable growth. We also welcome its clarification that wages, pensions and other crucial elements of a nation’s social system are issues for subsidiarity which Member States themselves should decide on, without intervention from the European Union. The report makes limited reference to exploring the concept of a European Treasury to support the economic pillar of Economic and Monetary Union. It is a matter for eurozone Members to determine whether such an institution is to be put in place for the eurozone, but Labour MEPs do not support any implication that such bodies should apply to non-eurozone Member States.

intervention.name: Mairead McGUINNESS
intervention.p: The European Semester involves the monitoring of the Member States’ economic, budgetary and employment policies and the identification of growth-enhancing measures to assist in the achievement of national targets under the EU 2020 strategy. In the context of the current economic crisis, a European Semester that aims to ensure sustained convergence of the economic and fiscal performance of the Member States is to be welcomed. Overcoming the sovereign debt crisis requires a closer coordination of economies, which this report advocates. I voted to support this report.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: As the European Semester is a process for coordinating Member States’ economic policies, it is implemented by the European Union to impose budgetary discipline and to ensure compliance with the Europe 2020 strategy. It is very important that the European institutions have adopted new measures aimed at helping the Member States to correct excessive deficits and to achieve greater coordination of their economic and budgetary policies.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: I voted against the European Commission proposal on economic governance and coordination, known as the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination, because it means giving more power to the markets, confirming the commitment to deregulation and giving them – in other words, the oligopolies made up of big multinationals and the financial sector – free rein to do business, filling a few pockets with privatised rights in the name of austerity and cuts. This initiative leaves national parliaments with their hands tied, imposing EU supervision over their budgets to make sure they keep the markets happy at all times, regardless of whether or not the budgets reflect the needs and demands of the people in each Member State. These are more than sufficient reasons to vote against the proposal.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: The euro crisis is closely linked to the differences between Member States with regard to their economic and budgetary policies. The establishment of a ‘European Semester’ or ‘economic governance’ was therefore vital. The aim, with this new EU economic and budgetary policy coordination tool, is to check that Member States are applying budgetary discipline and to ensure that the Europe 2020 programme is being implemented properly by granting it adequate financial resources. With the introduction of the European Semester, we are one step closer to European integration. However, we should remember that parliamentary debate on the main economic policy guidelines is the cornerstone of every democratic system. Democratic debate must not be overlooked. I therefore fully support Ms Berès when she calls for complete transparency with regard to the amendments made to the country-specific recommendations following discussions with the Member States.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: The initial goal of the report was to assess the first cycle of the European Semester. With the new developments on economic governance, the scope of the report has been broadened to focus on the way to upgrade the parliamentary dimension of economic governance with two main proposals: reinforce the European Parliament’s role within a codecision process for the European Semester; and reinforce cooperation between the European Parliament and national parliaments. In favour.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: It is a sad fact for the entire global economy that the Eurocrats in Brussels have failed to take any constructive steps in dealing with the financial and economic crisis that has lasted since 2008. What is even worse is the fact that the European leadership continues to close its eyes to any sensible alternative for resolving the problem. Instead, they continue along the wrong path first chosen at the end of the 1990s, when the euro was launched. In their desperation, the Eurocrats can think of no better remedy than to call for even greater centralisation in Brussels. However, instead of shifting more powers to Brussels with the European Semester, what we should be doing is preventing the indebtedness in the first place. In view of the morass that is the debt crisis, the priority should be at all costs to prevent the economically sound members of the euro area from being dragged into the abyss too. Since the European Semester does not offer any rational solutions in this regard, I voted against it.

intervention.name: Claudio MORGANTI
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I decided to vote against this report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. This is because the entire analysis is based on and geared towards the Europe 2020 strategy, an initiative that is completely failing to bear the expected fruits, perhaps partly as a result of the crisis. However, it is not the first time that these much heralded strategies have turned out to be overwhelming failures, and the crisis cannot be used as an excuse for the expected failure of the Europe 2020 strategy as well. Focusing many of the objectives of economic policy coordination on this strategy looks to me like a move that is risky at best. I must also add that, in various points, it seems to be a case of coordinating the social policies of Member States, rather than their economies. The semester of coordination has only been in place for a few months, but I think that its value and meaning ought to be different from the content of this report.

intervention.name: Franz OBERMAYR
intervention.p: Instead of finally giving a chance to weaker national economies outside the euro area, Brussels is now placing its hopes in a planned economy. Economic and social policy, in other words, the key competences of a sovereign state, are now subject to the centralist monitoring of the Commission and the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (Ecofin). National reform programmes have to be presented in Brussels so that ‘anomalies can be identified at an early stage’. The recommendations of the Council and the Commission are then to be implemented in the second semester. This system will never work. This is not just my opinion – a study by the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance comes to the same conclusion: it estimates the efficiency of the recommendations in the last semester as non-existent. Why is that? Growth cannot be forced through a centralised planned economy. We need to remedy the mistakes made when the euro area was established and form a hard currency zone. This must be made up of sovereign states with sovereign economic policies. For this reason, I have voted against this report.

intervention.name: Rolandas PAKSAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution because well learnt lessons from the past can provide a bridge to a successful future. When assessing the experience of the first wave of the crisis, EU institutions and Member States should not just look differently at the future but also examine the current situation differently, but this is often not the case. However, the world has changed significantly in recent years. The directives being adopted are not effective enough to overcome the new challenges arising every day and ever growing old challenges in the economic, financial and social fields. Today, the main issue on the EU agenda is that of the scale of unemployment in Member States. We must implement urgent measures and programmes to ensure that unemployment is reduced by at least a third as quickly as possible. I believe that the Commission should, as soon as possible, envisage and submit specific plans laying down measures which enable progress to be made in implementing the main immediate and short-term objectives in the areas of job creation, innovation, education, energy and social inclusion.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: We have adopted the ‘six-pack’, and the two new regulations proposed by the Commission last week further emphasise fiscal and budgetary discipline and supervision by the EU institutions. Quite rightly, we need to go back to having rules on budgetary discipline, and procedures must be automatic. However, we cannot forget growth, because if we straightjacket our state budgets through unbending rules, while also requiring rigorous structural reforms, then, at the same time, we have to bring in measures to stimulate growth. Otherwise, in overall terms, Europe or many Member States risk falling into recession. Amidst all this, we cannot forget the relationship with our citizens and that is why, in the report by Ms Berès on the European Semester, we are asking for greater involvement from the national parliaments and from this House. That is because what this crisis has shown, above all in the search for responses, is precisely the lack of unity and political leadership and the democratic deficit with our citizens.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for this report because I agree with its main thrusts and recommendations. I would like to stress the need for the Commission and the Member States to step up support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which constitute the backbone of the single market economy, in accordance with the findings of the Annual Growth Survey, in particular, by fully implementing the Small Business Act, and by means of a package of measures to eliminate the obstacles faced by SMEs when accessing funding. Such a measure is of extreme importance in the outermost regions.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: The aim of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination was to introduce a way of synchronising European and national economic and financial policies. Today, any effort to conceptualise the political world that attempts to explain the current reality will tend to point to a ‘web-like political reality’ or, rather, ‘polyarchical’ power and webs of ‘interconstitutionality’. The purpose of this is to explain how the decisions made by one political player have an impact on all the others.

The real issue is therefore to determine to what extent democratic legitimacy can be brought to bear at a time when traditional decision-making procedures no longer appear to be offering a suitable response. Therefore, while it is no longer possible to preserve the traditional concept of sovereignty, which, in practice, would be profoundly unrealistic, it is still possible to secure the concurrence of powers and to involve the national parliaments and the European Parliament, which are directly legitimised institutions, as fellow players. If not, political power will lose a significant part of its legitimacy, which will jeopardise the basic choices that need to be made. I voted in favour, since I believe the report addresses these issues.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The outcome of the draft report (see link A7-0384/2011) of the ECON committee is the result of a long process. Nine committees drafted opinions which are well reflected in the final text as the rapporteur decided to vote most of them in a chapter called ‘sectoral contributions to the European Semester’. More than 350 amendments were tabled in ECON. In order to avoid the ‘left-right’ clash of the economic governance package, Ms Berès opted for a smart and inclusive process of negotiation which led to a good outcome. Most key Green amendments (47) survived through the negotiation process, including the following very good elements: - The EP commits to organise a public hearing to hold a dialogue based on the ‘comply or explain’ principle with the Commission and the Council at which the recommendations from the Commission, and the changes introduced by the Council, would be discussed. - The report emphasises that the guidelines for the employment policies of Member States and the broad economic guidelines both form integral parts of the European Semester and are equally important for the achievement of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The report also asks the Council and the Commission to ensure that all policy recommendations are consistent with the integrated guidelines.

intervention.name: Tokia SAÏFI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In May 2010, the Commission proposed the introduction of a semester of stricter budgetary surveillance. This process has been in force since January 2011. The objective of the European Semester is to strengthen coordination between Member States and European institutions while the budget lines for the following year are still at the draft stage. In particular, it is about ensuring that national budgets are fully compatible, firstly, with the stability or convergence programmes presented a few months earlier and, secondly, with the economic guidelines laid down at European level. During those six months (January to July), the budgetary and structural policies of Member States will be reviewed, on the basis of the information they provide, in order to identify any possible inconsistencies or signs of imbalance. I supported this resolution on the first European Semester because it calls for, among other things, increased parliamentary control of euro area governance at national and European level alike. It is only right that the people’s representatives be involved in strengthening the legitimacy of Community action and analysing the measures proposed.

intervention.name: Nikolaos SALAVRAKOS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report by Ms Berès because I consider that she has presented a very good text which strikes a balance between the social and economic dimensions of economic governance measures. The emphasis needs to be on growth and the competitiveness of the EU. This being so, it is a good idea to harmonise the national economic policies of the Member States of the EU in order to meet EU 2020 strategy targets.

intervention.name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: What is known as the European Semester, or, in other words, procedures for coordinating the economic policy of the EU Member States, has now been in force for a year. This procedure was introduced in the wake of the economic crisis that emerged largely as a result of excessive debt.

Today, we are at the epicentre of the biggest economic crisis in the history of the EU, and we can be quite sure that the European Semester is not enough to restore the confidence of financial markets or to restore growth. It is obvious that it must be followed up with more measures, which we eagerly await. At the moment, in the first year of the European Semester, it is difficult to predict whether this instrument will perform its function. Although more and more Member States are implementing the Commission’s recommendations, such as raising the pension age, facilitating access to capital and using public procurement to stimulate the economy, we still lack determination and coordination at European level. We must hope that, along with a streamlined European Semester, future solutions for the coordination of EU economic policy, which we expect soon following the December summit, will deliver the expected results and contribute to Europe’s rapid recovery from the debt crisis.

intervention.name: József SZÁJER
intervention.p: During the crisis, it has become clear to all of us that the EU must engage in stricter budgetary control. Accordingly, under the European Semester, our principal aim is to coordinate Member State budgetary and economic policies in line with the Stability and Growth Pact and the Europe 2020 economic strategy.

The most important task ahead of us now is to create an instrument for the prevention of future public debt crises which is effective at Community level. However, a vital prerequisite of this is the introduction of stricter sanctions. The greatest merit of the legislative ‘six-pack’ drafted during the Hungarian Presidency is that it gave priority to keeping state expenditures in check, and to the importance of the debt criterion.

Increased coordination of Member State economic policies is a necessary but insufficient condition of recovery from the crisis. In order for us to be able to manage the consequences of the recession and establish a sustainable economic policy, we must, in any event, pursue stricter budgetary control. Hungary has already embarked on this path. Unfortunately, my country is among the most indebted in Europe. The extreme amount of state debt we currently have is a result of irresponsible management by previous socialist governments.

In order to put an end to the indebtedness of the country once and for all, Hungary has adopted provisions at constitutional level on responsible budgetary management and a state debt limit this year.

I recommend that European Union Member States follow the example of the Hungarian Basic Law. They should put a constitutional stop to indebtedness so as to prevent another Greek, Irish or Portuguese crisis.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The European Semester is a process for coordinating Member States’ economic policies, and is implemented by the European Union to enforce budgetary discipline as well as to ensure compliance with the Europe 2020 strategy. I agree with this report because the European institutions have adopted new measures aimed at helping Member States to correct excessive deficits and to establish greater coordination of their economic and budgetary policies.

However, I should like to point out that the European Semester cannot, and should not, replace the democratic legitimacy of the European Parliament and national parliaments; the situation should always be monitored by the respective parliamentary committee. As a member of the Committee on Regional Development, I should like to stress that a strong and properly financed cohesion policy is the only effective and efficient instrument for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy. It is therefore important to highlight its long-term development programmes, budgetary dimension and decentralised management system.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The economic and financial crisis has made some Member States cut public expenditure and investment in areas which are essential to Europe’s citizens, such as health and education. I regard it as important that both the Commission and the Council ensure that sustainable, inclusive growth is at the heart of all the policy proposals made as part of the European Semester, along with employment and job creation. The measures adopted as part of the national reform plans, aimed at implementing economic governance and the European Semester, must not exacerbate the social crisis. I advocate that the recommendations from the Commission and Council must be mainly focused on a social policy conducive to education and vocational training, access to employment, the reintegration of the unemployed into the labour market and better coordination of Member States’ social welfare systems. Furthermore, the EU must consolidate the internal market and remove the barriers preventing workers’ mobility within the EU. I call for the Commission’s recommendations, specific to each country, to be accompanied by assessments of the social impact, taking into account the promotion of employment and the guarantee of access to education and ongoing training programmes.

intervention.name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: I voted against the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination because, although it adopts a relatively critical tone, it is still in keeping with the Europe 2020 strategy, with the efforts to strengthen the single market and the ‘six-pack’, and, in particular, with the Wortmann-Kool report. This just goes to show that some MEPs are talking out of both sides of their mouths. There is no point in saying here that parliamentary approval of public budgets is one of the foundations of democracy when the legislative texts say otherwise. Yet again, economic policies are being prioritised over social issues. This report will have no effect on current European policies. I therefore have no reason to change my vote against the ‘six-pack’.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The European Semester mechanism ensures the coordination of the necessary budgetary policy and fiscal policy between the Member States, giving them enough room for effective budgetary, economic and social measures. The much-vaunted synergy effects can only be optimised through this coordination. In essence, the European Parliament requires that sufficient resources should be set aside at an early stage, so that the objectives of the 2020 strategy can be implemented. I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am voting for this report and will highlight some of the most relevant points for strengthening our internal market: the possibility of using a European professional card; an effective conflict resolution system; a single point of contact; the review of public procurement legislation and the commitment of the Heads of State or Government to comply with the Single Market Act.

intervention.name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: The proper and smooth functioning of the single market is an essential condition for the free movement of people, goods, services and capital within the EU and for ensuring its economic development. We will mark an important event in 2012 – the twentieth anniversary of the creation of the single market, and it is therefore important to know and understand how the single market will develop in the future and what the concerns and expectations of participants in the single market are. In October this year, the Single Market Forum, organised at the initiative of the Commission and the Polish Presidency, showed that there are still many legal and administrative obstacles to the smooth functioning of the single market. I believe that implementation of the Single Market Act should be monitored at the highest political level, and that the Commission should regularly review its implementation and the transposition of the relevant legislation into Member States’ national law and issue reports. I welcome the fact that the resolution calls for the completion of the digital single market and for remaining technical barriers to cross-border trade and service provision to be overcome, in particular, by improving the mutual recognition of electronic IDs, electronic signatures and electronic documents. I wish to stress the importance of establishing common principles of public procurement at EU level since this would enable a number of remaining administrative and bureaucratic obstacles to be eliminated and would provide more opportunities, in particular for SMEs, to develop cross-border activities.

intervention.name: Regina BASTOS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The single market has brought about enormous benefits for the 500 million European citizens and has given European businesses new opportunities to expand. This resolution suggests that the points of single contact be developed into fully-fledged e-Government centres allowing entrepreneurs to submit and manage administrative formalities online.

The Digital Single Market will only be complete once technical setbacks to cross-border trade and to the provision of cross-border services have been overcome. The public procurement sector needs to be professionalised, and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) need to step up their involvement in the award of public contracts. This resolution also suggests the use of an effective, accessible and straightforward alternative dispute-resolution system. It is clear that the Digital Single Market promotes innovation, which, with the support of the Commission’s coordinated initiatives and the commitment of the Member States, will create new opportunities for businesses, particularly SMEs. This will encourage job creation and social cohesion and will lead to sustainable economic growth; it will also meet the social needs of European consumers and citizens. I voted for this resolution for these reasons.

intervention.name: Alain CADEC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the resolution on the Single Market Forum. The creation of this forum is part of the Single Market Act, which is a strategic document for planning legislative and non-legislative initiatives aimed at relaunching the single market in 2012. The resolution sets out proposals for ensuring that the forum is used as an opportunity to relaunch the single market, which makes a significant contribution to Europe’s competitiveness, effectively.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I have voted in favour of this resolution as I support the conversion of the Single Market Forum into a regular event, with the purpose of enabling businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to participate directly in and influence the further development of the Single Market.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The single market and the policies related to it have brought benefits to 500 million European consumers and 21 million European businesses and have become the engine for economic growth. At this moment, when everything is taking place at a European level, I must underline the importance of the single market for European integration itself, greater social cohesion, sustainable development, economic competitiveness and growth, which enable us to face up to present constraints and future developments and to compete in a globalised world. In this regard, I welcome the idea of establishing a forum which meets regularly to consider the future and the development of the single market.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: The present motion for a resolution, tabled in response to a statement by the Commission pursuant to Rule 110(2) of the Rules of Procedure, concerns the first Single Market Forum, held in the Polish city of Kraków on 3-4 October 2011. The economic crisis cannot make us oblivious to the human aspects of the reforms, such as the wellbeing of citizens, consumers, workers and savers. The purpose of this forum, which involved more than 1 300 participants (businesses, social partners, NGOs, European institutions, public authorities, etc.), was to discuss strategies for improving the functioning of the single market, such as promoting freedom of movement among European citizens through the automatic recognition of professional qualifications, speeding up the online Alternative Dispute Resolution system, transforming Points of Single Contact, protecting the interests of online purchasers, creating the European patent, etc. I am voting in favour of this resolution and welcome the attention it gives to small and medium-sized enterprises, the real engines of the European economy, which have the power to bring about recovery from the current economic and financial crisis by means of sustainable economic growth, thus making the single market economy increasingly dynamic and competitive.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: We have here an initiative and a resolution that are highly significant for the majority in this Parliament. The first recital in the resolution is, in fact, very revealing when it declares that ‘the European Single Market has brought tremendous benefits to 500 million Europeans, whilst opening up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses, and has become the real engine for growth within the European economy’. This ignores a basic fact: in the actual conditions under which this process of integration is taking place, the opportunities referred to really have arisen for some people, while, for others, they have remained mere promises, endlessly postponed, and have turned into nightmares.

Some have experienced real expansion, others only a long-drawn-out death and disappearance. Free-market competition has made life easy for the sections of society that wield economic and financial power, but has aggravated unemployment, increased the rate of bankruptcy among countless small and medium-sized enterprises, and done nothing to improve the day-to-day lives of the general population, as the present crisis is making plain. It is for these reasons that, on being presented with such a picture as this resolution puts before us, our only response can be to protest against the pressure being exerted here to entrench the single market yet further, which the rhetoric of ‘consultation’ and ‘participation’ essentially does nothing to change.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: We have voted against this resolution, which declares as its very first point: ‘whereas the European Single Market has brought tremendous benefits to 500 million Europeans, whilst opening up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses, and has become the real engine for growth within the European economy’. Really, such a declaration cannot be allowed to pass when we bear in mind that free-market competition has made life easy for the sections of society that wield economic and financial power, but has aggravated unemployment, increased the rate of bankruptcy among micro-enterprises and SMEs and done nothing to improve the day-to-day lives of the general population, as the present crisis is making plain.

Thus, even though the Single Market Forum may be converted into a regular event to enable businesses and citizens, as well as local and regional authorities, to participate directly in and influence the further development of the single market, the truth remains that the current state of affairs is quite different from that proclaimed in this report. Similarly, we disagree with the pressure being exerted here to further entrench the single market.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: The European Single Market has brought tremendous benefits to 500 million Europeans, whilst opening up new opportunities for expansion for more than 21 million European businesses, and has become the real engine for growth within the European economy. In a large number of areas, there is still a gap between what people expect from the single market and what they experience in practice. The first Single Market Forum brought together European businesses, social partners, non-governmental organisations, think-tanks, journalists, national Parliaments, European institutions, public authorities at various levels of government and European citizens. It is important that this forum becomes a regular event, to enable businesses and citizens as well as local and regional authorities to directly participate in, and thereby collectively influence, the further development of the single market. I believe that it would be appropriate to create a Single Market Forum on-line, as a platform open to the general public, enabling them to keep abreast of single market developments and share experiences and current single market concerns. It is necessary for governments, regional and local entities, businesses, trade unions and non-governmental organisations to cooperate to ensure that single market rules work effectively on the ground for citizens and businesses.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I supported this resolution, as it sets out the main lessons learnt from the first Single Market Forum, held in Kraków last October. In my opinion, this initiative is very important when it comes to analysing and debating the shortcomings of the internal market and to finding solutions to strengthen it.
