However, recent political events, namely the use of judicial means for political purposes, demonstrate that there is still a long way to go to make future membership of the EU possible, in particular, complying with all of the conditions that the rule of law demands.

intervention.name: Alajos MÉSZÁROS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Ukraine’s political leadership has demonstrated its commitment to European integration on several occasions. In doing so, it has deserved the conclusion of the association agreement, which would create a never before seen degree of integration between the European Union and Ukraine.

However, the imprisonment of Yulia Tymoshenko and the trials against other ministers in an attempt to prevent them from participating in next year’s parliamentary elections raise serious concerns. Recently, there have been concerns over the freedom of the press and the rule of law as well, not to mention the fact that Russia is trying to pressure its neighbour into refraining from signing a free trade agreement with the EU.

Despite all this, I do believe that we should take the necessary steps for the implementation of the association agreement. Ukraine must make a commitment to reforms, democratic values and the strengthening of human rights. We must provide appropriate financial, technical and legal assistance and support the preparation of anti-corruption policy in the country. We must also assist in negotiations with Russia, as well as in the field of energy security, in order to be able to strengthen the energy cooperation the country has entered into with the European Union.

intervention.name: Willy MEYER
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: There is no way I could have voted in favour of this report, since it is a clear interference in the internal affairs of Ukraine. The aim of the association agreement currently being negotiated by the European Union and Ukraine is to establish a free trade zone between the two regions, which will not be beneficial to the populations of either of them, but instead to the economic interests of the EU. Meanwhile, the EU is also imposing a European perspective in this association agreement. This is nothing short of an obligation requiring Ukraine to introduce internal reforms and systematic and irreversible changes in a wide range of significant social, economic, political and institutional areas, which have already been undertaken or are in the process of being undertaken. In my view, this is unacceptable interference in the country’s sovereignty, and that is why I voted against this report.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: Since Ukraine gained its independence in 1992, the European Union has worked unceasingly to develop bilateral relations with its eastern neighbour. The countless resolutions adopted recently in Parliament are along the same lines. The association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine represents the natural progression of this positive and constructive approach. In addition to the mutual economic benefits, the conclusion of this agreement should help Ukraine to make progress in becoming a democratic State that is based on the rule of law and which guarantees citizens’ fundamental rights. Democracy involves complex requirements that go beyond the right to vote and respect for elections. Democracy entails protecting rights and freedoms, respecting due process, but also guaranteeing open discussion and encouraging debate. Above all, democracy means freedom of expression. Having a majority does not justify tyranny by the majority. Democracy means constructive opposition, a free and informed civil society, and an independent press.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Ukraine’s association with the EU provides the best possibility for overcoming recent negative trends in the country and I welcome the perspective of the association agreement. In favour.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: There is no question that the European Union should maintain good relations with Ukraine, particularly in terms of economic and scientific cooperation. However, it should not be forgotten that an association agreement with Ukraine that aims for the country’s full accession to the EU in the long or short term, will doubtless also entail a deterioration in relations with Russia. Furthermore, the judgment against Ukraine’s former Prime Minister, Yulia Tymoshenko, in a political show trial has demonstrated that Ukraine still has some way to go in terms of the rule of law and democratic values. All of this leads to a climate in which it would be unwise to conclude such an agreement. For that reason, I abstained.

intervention.name: Radvilė MORKŪNAITĖ-MIKULĖNIENĖ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour. Ukraine has been at a crossroads for some time. It is important for the country’s political elite to have sufficient political will to maintain a European course, not just economically but also in terms of values. I hope that Ukraine will, in the near future, implement the reforms necessary in the area of justice and will ensure Yulia Tymoshenko’s right to an appeal and that all opposition groups have the opportunity to participate unhindered in political processes and in elections. On the other hand, the EU should support Ukraine’s European aspirations. Ukraine is one of the most advanced ENP countries, and its success story will encourage other Eastern Partnership countries to follow suit. I hope that EU Heads of State will give the green light to the association agreement before the end of the year.

intervention.name: Siiri OVIIR
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: I supported this resolution, which recognises Ukraine’s existing contribution and achievements in connection with the association agreement and, at the same time, draws attention to important matters that need to be resolved. I do not, however, approve of the European Parliament continually speaking out in defence of former Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, who has been convicted of corruption in a court of law, since the truth in this matter is not black and white. I am, however, glad to note that the negotiations with Ukraine are among the most advanced in the Eastern European region and are an example for the European Neighbourhood Policy as a whole. The association agreement to be concluded with Ukraine will be altogether broader, signifying substantive integration into Europe and opening up Ukraine’s prospects of becoming a member of the EU at a future date.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Many commercial agreements have been in place for some time between the European Union and Ukraine in order to simplify legislation on trade with Europe or bring in new procedures to incentivise imports and exports. I, too, voted in favour of the report by Mr Legutko, which moves towards replacing the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement in force since 1998 with the more thorough association agreement enabling further negotiations to be opened and additional agreements to be made. In this way, Ukraine will reach an unprecedented level of integration with the EU in terms of relations with third countries. Furthermore, through this agreement, the negotiations between the EU and Ukraine will be among the most advanced with our eastern neighbours, thereby setting an example for the European Neighbourhood Policy as a whole.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution, in which I draw attention to the request to step up cooperation with regard to youth and student exchanges and the development of scholarship programmes, thereby enabling Ukrainians to become acquainted with the European Union and its Member States, and vice versa.

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: With the European Union’s recent enlargement, Ukraine has come to border the common area. It is a state of great geostrategic importance, not only as a possible commercial partner, but, primarily, as a guarantor of peace and security in a region where the establishment of the rule of law is not yet assured. In this context, an example to be remembered is the recent concern about fair legal process (in the matter of the detention of Yulia Tymoshenko). However, these elements should contribute not to aggravating distrust between the two areas, but, above all, to motivating EU action to support Ukraine, based on mutual recognition between the two areas. The EU can assert itself, in this context, as a true regional power in respecting human rights and defending the rule of law. To this extent, I welcome the resolution tabled and have voted in favour.

intervention.name: Mitro REPO
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the proposal. The association agreement is a logical and, at the same time, very important step in EU-Ukraine relations. With this agreement, Ukraine is committing itself to implementing a large portion of the acquis communautaire . Ukraine is a country of strategic importance, owing to its size and location. Ukraine’s European perspective is important for security, stability and prosperity in Europe as a whole. The new generation in civil society is educated and did not experience the Soviet era. The new generation has strong pro-European ambitions. This will enable Ukraine to modernise.

However, recent reports on a decline in the freedom of the media and of civil society, problems in the conduct of elections, and cracks in the system with regard to the rule of law, must be taken seriously. As a European country, Ukraine is welcome as a member of the EU, as long as it first meets all the membership criteria. Moreover, the EU should be honest and consistent: Europe must therefore keep its promises.

intervention.name: Robert ROCHEFORT
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: It is entirely in the European Union’s interest to foster relations with third countries that can be beneficial to both parties in terms of political stability or even economic access. The association agreement currently being negotiated between the EU and Ukraine reflects this thinking, particularly in view of Ukraine’s geopolitical significance, its history and resources, but also goes even further. It presages a new, more ambitious kind of agreement, offering even greater opportunities, because it assumes that a significant portion of the acquis communautaire will be implemented in the third country in question. I therefore welcome the vote on Mr Legutko’s report, which supports these negotiations while also expressly calling for the rule of law and human rights to be respected. A specific reference is made to the alarming sentence recently given to the former Prime Minister, Yulia Tymoshenko. I also particularly welcome the European Parliament’s willingness to resume the essential and effective dialogue with President Yanukovych, the calls for legal and electoral reform, and the project for improving cooperation on energy with a view to guaranteeing Europe’s security of supply.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. The EP addresses, in the context of the ongoing negotiations on the association agreement, the following recommendations to the Council, the Commission and the EEAS: (a) to take the view that a deepening of relations between the EU and Ukraine and the fact of offering Ukraine a European perspective are of great significance and in the interests of both parties; to recognise Ukraine’s aspirations pursuant to Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union, provided that all criteria, including respect for the principles of democracy, human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law, are met; (b) to make the necessary progress in order to achieve the rapid initialling of an EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, preferably by the end of 2011 if possible; to ensure, at the same time, in line with the demands made in Parliament’s resolution of 27 October 2011, that this important initiative within the Eastern Partnership goes hand in hand with commitments by Ukraine to implement the necessary reforms and strengthen democratic values, human rights and the rule of law.

intervention.name: Tokia SAÏFI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: As the Vice-Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and a member of the Committee on International Trade, I have followed all the work done on these recommendations. I approved the Committee on International Trade’s decision to postpone its vote on the day that Yulia Tymoshenko was sentenced. The decision sent a signal to Ukraine: not only does the European Union promote its values; it does not hesitate to defend those values in practice. The recommendations presented in plenary take this consideration fully into account, and I therefore voted in favour. However, I will continue to monitor the negotiations closely, because in addition to my concerns about human rights, I also have some questions about the content of the section on trade in this agreement. On that last point, it will be important to ensure that Ukraine agrees to make real concessions, particularly on eliminating tariff and non-tariff barriers to exports, and accepting geographical indications.

intervention.name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: On 1 March 1998, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was signed between the EU and Ukraine. It was the first step towards closer relations between the two countries. The next step, representing a framework for closer cooperation, is to be an association agreement between the EU and Ukraine. This will result in a partial implementation of EU law in Ukraine’s legal system, and closer economic and political ties.

However, it should be pointed out that the recent arrest of the former Prime Minister of Ukraine, Yulia Tymoshenko, has negative implications for the conclusion of the abovementioned association agreement, and calls into question the efficiency of democratic action and the independence of the courts in Ukraine. It therefore seems justified to add a legal mechanism to the future agreement, allowing the possible suspension of the agreement in the event that the relevant provisions are deliberately ignored by the Ukrainian Government.

The future association agreement should regulate in detail matters relating to economic and trade cooperation. I think that a key issue here that requires further work is cooperation on energy matters. This is indispensable for the joint diversification of energy sources and securing the transit of fuels from Russia. It is also necessary to combat corruption among officials. The agreement must also require Ukraine to introduce a visa-free regime between Ukraine and the EU. Such a solution could be put to the test during the 2012 European Football Championship.

intervention.name: Sergio Paolo Francesco SILVESTRIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The negotiations referred to in the report that we voted on this morning – namely the meeting of 19 December – are still hanging in the balance. This is because, a few days ago, the Ukrainian President, Mr Yanukovych, ended a discussion with the press about his presence or absence from the EU-Ukraine Summit by saying that he would be there ‘when necessary for Ukrainian national interests’. This mysterious outburst therefore leaves some doubt over whether he will attend. At a historic moment when the Ukrainian Government and the EU could sign an association agreement with which the EU would grant Ukraine the status of favoured partner, as enjoyed by Iceland, Switzerland and Norway, Mr Yanukovych seems to want to play hard to get. I would like Parliament to reflect on this lack of involvement from the party that should have the greatest interest in attending the summit. News of the Ukrainian Head of State’s attendance at the Eurasian summit would be tantamount to an insult orchestrated by the presidential administration to raise the stakes with the EU in the final days of negotiations prior to the entry into force of the association agreement: namely, an assessment of a request from Ukraine to join the EU in the next 10 years.

intervention.name: Csaba Sándor TABAJDI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: It would be important for the association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine to be initialled before the year is out. The agreement would add a new quality to the relations between the EU and Ukraine, and can be considered an important step towards the creation of an EU-Ukraine free trade area, closer cooperation in the field of energy, and Ukrainian visa exemption.

However, Ukraine’s leadership must cease its efforts to hold Yulia Tymoshenko accountable for previous political decisions on the basis of a law that is a remnant of Soviet times and is being applied selectively. The Ukrainian judiciary must be allowed to conduct the appeal procedure under fair circumstances.

This case highlights the fact that there is much headway to be made in Ukraine with regard to strengthening the independence of the judiciary and reducing corruption. The independence of the judiciary is a fundamental value which the European Union must apply not only outside its borders but within them as well.

Efforts to convict a former Head of Government for previous economic and political decisions can occur not only in Ukraine but also in the European Union, namely in Hungary. The European Union must take firm action against politically motivated show trials within its own borders as well.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The exploitation of judicial institutions for party and political ends, as has been seen in Ukraine, shows that there are still obstacles to the promotion of the rights and fundamental guarantees of Ukrainian citizens. The events of last month put one of the fundamental values of the EU at risk: the rule of law and freedom of expression and of the media.

This association agreement, which also includes a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA), is a document that opens a new door to agreements between the EU and third countries, since it presupposes a very high degree of integration, through the incorporation of the acquis communautaire . This type of agreement must serve as an example for the neighbourhood policy countries, leaving the possibility of future membership open.

The reforms policy that Ukraine is implementing is centred on institutional, economic and social areas. The strategic importance of the Ukraine to the EU is undeniable. Nevertheless, we must avoid double-dealing and forgetting the constituent principles of the EU, which are the foundation of all European policies. In my opinion, it is important to obtain the commitment of the Ukrainian authorities to restoring the rule of law.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: An intensification of relations with Ukraine is of enormous interest for the EU, particularly in the energy sector. For the current negotiations in relation to an association agreement with Ukraine, the European Parliament recommends that a meeting should be arranged with President Yanukovych before this month is over, so that the EU can air its concerns at recent events. In relation to the substance of the agreement, Parliament mainly calls for the inclusion of the most stringent environmental standards and the promotion of an improved investment climate by supporting Ukraine in pursuing the rule of law, legal certainty and judicial reform. I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Luís Paulo ALVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I am in favour of this report, the take-home message of which is that in order to set up a modern customs regime, we need to strengthen the European Union’s competitiveness, while at the same time ensuring security, market surveillance, consumer protection and our economic interests.

intervention.name: Elena Oana ANTONESCU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The customs service has a crucial role to play in guaranteeing safety and security, protecting consumers and the environment, strengthening the fight against fraud and corruption, and ensuring respect for intellectual property rights. A customs policy including well-functioning, efficient and simplified customs procedures plays a key role in combating the illegal entry of goods and counterfeit products into the single market, thereby enhancing safety and security for European consumers. The modernisation of the EU’s customs strategy and customs instruments is essential in contributing to the EU’s global economic competitiveness and to reliable trade relations with third countries. I voted in favour of this report.

intervention.name: Sophie AUCONIE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: In order to increase the competitiveness of European businesses and improve consumer safety, the European Parliament is advocating the modernisation of the electronic customs systems. Modernisation would entail harmonising the application of European customs legislation and simplifying customs procedures. As I believe that this modernisation is essential for an effective internal market, and for combating counterfeiting and protecting intellectual property rights, I voted in favour of Mr Salvini’s report.

intervention.name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: The customs union is one of the most important foundations for the free movement of goods, economic development and growth in the internal market. Customs play an important role in safeguarding the EU’s financial interests, as the importation into the EU of counterfeit and pirated goods leads to a loss in revenue and violates intellectual property rights, and counterfeit products can pose serious risks to the health and safety of European consumers. Customs today face increasing volumes of import, export and transit transactions while resources remain limited, and it is therefore important to ensure an efficient and effective management of customs procedures. I agree that the Modernised Customs Code adopted in 2008 is very important to improving the current situation and ensuring a smooth, simple and well-functioning customs system. I believe e-customs, in particular, centralised customs clearance, is one of the main aspects of customs modernisation and simplification for strengthening the EU’s economic competitiveness and developing reliable trade relations with third countries.

intervention.name: Elena BĂSESCU
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted for the report drafted by Mr Salvini because I believe that it is vital to the European Union’s competitiveness in the current market. I should emphasise the need to adapt the system to current requirements. This means that a differentiation must be made between the transit of perishable and non-perishable goods. Ensuring that the European market is supplied in a timely and safe manner is a priority nowadays for the EU. At the same time, the principle of proportionality must be observed with respect to the measures adopted by national authorities. An effective customs system is vital for the development of intellectual property rights, as emphasised in point 22. It also provides the transparency required for SMEs’ current activities, thereby facilitating economic growth. In Romania, one of the reform’s main objectives was to root out corruption in the customs service. This provides the basis for Romania joining the Schengen area, in addition to the restructuring of the border police.

intervention.name: Adam BIELAN
intervention.p: Modernisation of customs services is one of the tasks undertaken in order to facilitate business activities in the Union. Putting into practice the idea of centralised customs clearance, which will enable companies to notify goods electronically and make payments from their own office, may dramatically simplify customs procedures. Drafting an appropriate customs strategy, which is one of the priorities of the Member States, is also key for European competitiveness. It will help improve the protection of intellectual property rights and the fight against illegal imports of goods or counterfeit products. Another important matter relates to security issues, in terms of eliminating both imports of life-threatening materials and illegal immigration via freight transport. In order to be able to remain vigilant against the constant threat, the customs services must be placed in the best situation to ensure that only safe products that meet the legal requirements reach the Member States. I voted for the adoption of the report.

intervention.name: Alain CADEC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the Salvini report on modernisation of customs. The report points out that customs services need to have adequate resources in order to cope with their increased responsibilities. This goes hand in hand with the need to simplify, standardise and modernise customs legislation and procedures.

intervention.name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
intervention.p: I am in favour of an efficient Customs Union, as the free movement of goods forms one of the cornerstones of the European integration process, economic development and growth of the internal market. Since customs play a crucial role in maintaining security and consumer and environmental protection, ensuring that all duties are collected, strengthening the fight against fraud and corruption and safeguarding intellectual property rights, I am hereby expressing my support for their modernisation.

intervention.name: Carlos COELHO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The modernisation of customs regimes is a priority for ensuring security, protecting intellectual property, combating fraud, and updating and adapting systems to rapidly changing technology. This is a bold and reforming report. The Modernised Customs Code (MCC) adopted in 2008 plays a crucial role in simplifying European Union customs procedures and harmonising customs rules, and thus helps economic actors to work more efficiently and customs authorities to operate more effectively. However, the MCC cannot come into operation until the information systems have been put in place and/or developed. Consequently, progress so far suggests that the deadline for implementation (set for 24 June 2013) will not be met. However, I agree that it would be appropriate to delay the implementation of the MCC, since the great majority of Member States and trade representatives are in favour of this option. It is also important to ensure cooperation between customs authorities, and subsequently between customs authorities and economic actors as well as with government authorities. I agree that it may be necessary to create a European Customs Agency in order to bring this about.

intervention.name: Lara COMI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) - Vice
intervention.p: I am in favour of the proposal on the modernisation of customs. Customs are fundamentally important for international trade, which is why I think we need to simplify, standardise and modernise customs legislation and procedures. The different national interpretations of the EU customs legislation create red tape for business, with a consequent negative impact on European competitiveness. Modernising customs and introducing modern and efficient IT tools must be a high political priority, bringing clear added value to EU operators and small and medium-sized enterprises in particular. An effective customs policy plays a key role in protecting intellectual property rights, combating the illegal entry of goods and counterfeit products into the single market, and therefore enhances safety and security for European consumers. I do not, however, agree with Articles 41-46 on the issue of preferential origin, because I think it is reductive to provide ‘ready-made solutions’ right now to such a sensitive and long-debated issue. The most appropriate time to discuss this issue will be the ordinary procedure, which will take place with the forthcoming Commission legislative proposal to review the customs code.

intervention.name: Christine DE VEYRAC
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this report on modernising the European customs strategy. Now that EU internal border controls have been dismantled, customs authorities need to have sufficient resources to tackle new challenges, not least in terms of safety and preventing illegal trafficking.

intervention.name: Ioan ENCIU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this report because effective customs union is one of the cornerstones of the European integration process, as well as a strong basis for the free movement of goods, economic development and growth within the internal market. I support the fact that the customs service has a crucial role to play in guaranteeing safety and security, protecting consumers and the environment, as well as in strengthening the fight against fraud and corruption, and ensuring respect for intellectual property rights. I think that modernising the customs strategy should be a priority with a budget to match this ambition, as a good policy on efficient customs procedures can make a vital contribution to stimulating the EU’s global competitiveness. At the same time, I support the fact that customs administration must be modernised, and we need modernisation measures such as simpler customs legislation and interoperable computerised customs systems, which will help facilitate commercial practices. Last but not least, I support the fact that cooperation among the various stakeholders and institutions in the area of customs is essential to guarantee that the customs service fulfils its mission efficiently. I believe that we must ensure a prompt, transparent flow of information among all the stakeholders.

intervention.name: Edite ESTRELA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on modernisation of customs as its proposals would contribute to greater product safety and consumer protection, as well as strengthening the European Union’s competitiveness.

intervention.name: Diogo FEIO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The role of customs in European economic competitiveness is of major importance, since, in addition to ensuring the safety of citizens, they protect consumers and intellectual property rights, ensure that duties are paid, and contribute to the fight against fraud and corruption. They do need modernisation in order to fulfil these functions effectively. However, there are indications that not all Member States will meet the deadline for implementing the regulations setting up the Modernised Customs Code. This code will make it possible to introduce an electronic customs system, a one-stop system and a centralised service. Also, I agree with the rapporteur that greater cooperation between the various customs services is needed to enable improvements to its excellent work and rapid implementation of the Modernised Customs Code.

intervention.name: José Manuel FERNANDES
intervention.p: The European Union’s aim of creating a single market where barriers between Member States have disappeared, while only retaining its external borders with countries outside it, means that special measures need to be taken to avoid negative repercussions on Europe’s economic competitiveness, which is essential for the revival of the internal market. Matteo Salvini’s report, which I voted for, concerns modernisation of customs regimes and emphasises the role of customs in ensuring security and protection of property rights, protecting authors and combating fraud. The Modernised Customs Code, aimed at simplifying customs procedures and harmonising customs regulations, was adopted in 2008, with the deadline for implementation being 24 June 2013. However, several Member States have argued against this date because of delays in setting up the computerised systems needed in order for it to function. It is therefore urgent to resolve this problem, in view of the added value of the MCC, particularly in creating links between all the Member States, facilitating business activity by economic players and ensuring better control by tax authorities. It will also facilitate trade in legitimate goods and enhance product safety.

intervention.name: João FERREIRA
intervention.p: The report considers that a flexible, simple and functional customs system is essential for facilitating the flow of goods and trade within the internal market, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). We agree that the modernisation of the customs strategy and customs instruments in the EU requires a sufficient budget for a policy on functional, efficient and simplified customs procedures. However, we do have some reservations about the rapporteur’s vision, since, if taken to extremes, it might fail to take into account basic national interests and products, such as agriculture and other food-related areas. Moreover, it does not always take account of the interests of SMEs themselves, which face competition from much larger companies eager to gobble up chunks of the existing market as well as new markets.

In short, Member States should also ensure that adequate resources are available for the customs procedures and processes that are necessary in each case. In particular, it is essential to develop computerised systems for the customs modernisation that is needed. For this, customs must focus on using the limited resources available to reduce risks, to ensure the protection and safety of the market and of society, and to maintain border protection at the EU’s external borders.

intervention.name: Ilda FIGUEIREDO
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left - Vice
intervention.p: The report considers that a flexible, simple and functional customs system is essential for facilitating the flow of goods and trade within the internal market, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. We do not support this concept in its entirety, since it does not always take account of basic national interests and products, such as agriculture and other food-related areas. However, we agree that the modernisation of the customs strategy and customs instruments in the EU requires a budget that is sufficient for developing a policy on functional, efficient and simplified customs procedures.

Member States should ensure that resources keep pace with the ever-expanding responsibilities of customs, and adequate funding under the budget for customs procedures and processes, particularly for developing computerised systems, is essential for the customs modernisation that is needed. Customs must therefore focus on using the limited resources available to reduce risks, to ensure the protection and safety of the market and society, and to maintain border protection at the EU’s external borders. We abstained from the vote.

intervention.name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
intervention.p: The Customs Union of the European Union (EU) is a cornerstone of the EU. Since its creation, the Customs Union has been expanded both quantitatively – from 6 to 27 members, and qualitatively by becoming a Single Market. It has contributed to prosperity in Europe by facilitating trade both within the Union and with third countries. Today’s customs are facing a rapidly changing environment: evolving production and consumption patterns, increasing international trade, global threats such as terrorism, organised crime, climate change and new hazards like trade in dangerous goods. It is in precisely this context that the customs authorities of the EU play a key role. Their mission is to ensure at all times the balance between protecting society and facilitating trade through the control of the supply chain, at the external border as well as within the EU. I believe it is important to try to make an effort to modernise customs working methods, whereby the overarching objective is to maintain the pivotal position of customs authorities as a modern, responsive partner to trade, protecting the fiscal, consumer and security interests of the Union, cooperating with other government agencies, and, at the same time, being equipped to respond to crisis and new public policy demands.

intervention.name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Customs regulation at an appropriate level has a considerable role in improving competitiveness. In order for it to be able to fulfil its role completely, the customs system must be modern and efficient.

I agree with the rapporteur’s opinion that a timely and transparent flow of information among all the parties involved must be enabled. Additionally, the establishment of close cooperation between customs administrations and market surveillance authorities must obviously be encouraged in order to intercept non-compliant products at the borders.

This is one of the reason why I welcome the fact that the enhanced Customs Code allows the retention of goods suspected of violating intellectual property law, and thus comprises one of the pillars of the Union’s legal framework for the protection of intellectual property rights.

I ask the Commission and the Member States to implement all the aforesaid, and to provide their officials with appropriate training in order to make the detection of products that pose a risk even more effective.

intervention.name: Mikael Gustafsson, Cornelis de Jong
intervention.p: Today, I have voted in favour of the Salvini report on the Modernisation of Customs, but I strongly disagree with the wording in paragraph 76, where the Commission is encouraged to push forward the conclusion of the Doha Round.

intervention.name: Juozas IMBRASAS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: By 2013, all Member States’ customs are supposed to introduce the same IT equipment, and because they will not manage to do so, it is proposed that this date be postponed. Firms also state that it will be difficult for them to adapt to the new rules so quickly. This proposal has been submitted to the Commission. I believe that this is an important tool for streamlining and truly harmonising customs procedures in order to contribute to the strengthening of the European economy. I also support the view that the widespread use of simplified customs procedures for imports, which are aimed at reducing customs formalities and control before the release of goods, is one of the key elements of the EU’s customs policy. Over 71% of all customs procedures have been simplified, but those procedures have led to unjustified levels of losses to the Union budget and breaches in the EU’s trade policy. European economic competitiveness is of paramount importance, especially with a view to revitalising the internal market. Customs has a significant role to play in improving and influencing competitiveness as the simplification of customs legislation and promotion of electronic customs stimulate economic growth. In order to fulfil its potential, customs has to be modern, cooperative, responsive and active.

intervention.name: Philippe JUVIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Mr Salvini’s report, which stresses the crucial role that customs services play in protecting the internal market and consumers. In particular, modernisation should include simplifying procedures, taking into account SMEs’ needs and expectations, and increasing protection for consumers and intellectual property rights. At the same time, I feel that the list-based rules should be extended unreservedly in order to reflect the general principle that the non-preferential origin of goods is determined by where their last substantial processing took place. This will allow us to clarify the legal framework and thereby reduce costs for economic operators. Consequently, I did not support paragraph 45 of the report.

intervention.name: Edvard KOŽUŠNÍK
intervention.p_group: European Conservatives and Reformists Group
intervention.p: I recommend a high degree of caution ahead of calls for greater integration in the area of customs. I am therefore delighted that the amendment on the creation of a new European customs agency was rejected. In the area of modernisation, it is important to have two-way communications and a unified approach in respect of all Member States, and not deeper integration, the transfer of powers and the creation of more supra-national institutions, as some people often assume. In order to increase business competitiveness, it is important to focus on simplifying customs procedures and standardising customs threshold values, as well as applying the ‘one-stop shop’ principle in customs procedures. We should pay particular attention to the protection of intellectual property rights and to linking this protection to customs procedures.

intervention.name: Giovanni LA VIA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Improving customs with a view to making monitoring and checking procedures leaner and less problematic for businesses trading with third countries is needed now as never before. Trying to modernise the customs system and cutting red tape basically implies taking an approach based on subsidiarity to business. Understanding, at a time of crisis like the present, that we need greater flexibility and simpler trade processes for European business owners should lead to a political and economic awareness that is geared more closely to resolving particular problems. However, I think it is worth clarifying that greater flexibility does not run contrary to ongoing strictness in terms of checks and the safety of products that go through the customs systems of Member States. Safety and lower administrative costs for traders are two factors that can, in my view, go hand in hand in the customs modernisation process.

intervention.name: David MARTIN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for this report in which the rapporteur stresses the need to ensure cooperation among customs authorities, as well as between customs authorities and traders, customs authorities and other governmental authorities and, in that respect, strongly supports the coordinated border management, single window principle, one-stop shop concept and centralised customs clearance. The rapporteur also proposes to establish a European Customs Agency to deal with customs issues.

intervention.name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
intervention.p_group: Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left
intervention.p: The proposed simplification of the customs system may be helpful, to some extent, to all stakeholders in many areas. It should be economically beneficial, making life easier and boosting efficiency. Support for, and facilitation of, the conditions for doing business is thus one highly important aspect. Another aspect of no less importance is the improved efficiency of actual customs procedures, and greater effectiveness in the fight against trafficking. In my opinion, the relevant bodies (the customs administrations) will thus be better able to fulfil their obligations and, in many cases, their work will be made easier.

intervention.name: Clemente MASTELLA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: Customs has an increasingly significant role to play in improving and influencing competitiveness in the European Union. Simultaneously, it plays an essential role in ensuring efficient safety checks, protecting intellectual property rights and contributing to the fight against fraud. We agree with the rapporteur, Mr Salvini, on the need to modernise customs and to improve cooperation among the various stakeholders and institutions in the area of customs – including traders, customs authorities, other governmental agencies, the Commission and Parliament – which is essential if we are to guarantee that customs fulfils its mission We are therefore in favour of prompt and transparent flows of information between all the parties involved. We also believe that it is necessary to strike an appropriate balance between customs controls designed to ensure safety and the smooth movement of legitimate goods. However, we will need to ensure cooperation between all customs authorities, as well as between customs authorities, operators and other governmental authorities. Accordingly, we strongly support the idea of coordinated border management and the single window, one-stop shop and centralised customs clearance principles. We also support the creation of a European Customs Agency charged with dealing with customs issues.

intervention.name: Véronique MATHIEU HOUILLON
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s own-initiative report on modernisation of customs. Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to explore the possibilities of further increasing customs cooperation and harmonising customs rules in order to improve the functioning of the Customs Union. Simplification and modernisation of customs procedures, and the use of modern IT tools, are paramount. Thus, intensifying the fight against crime and the illegal entry of counterfeit goods and products will contribute to global EU competitiveness, thereby enabling businesses to receive reliable information about the market.

intervention.name: Mario MAURO
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I completely agree with the content and structure of this report. I think that increasing cooperation between Member States and all other stakeholders should be at the heart of everything. Mr Salvini is quite right to say that we need to bring in modernisation measures, such as simpler customs legislation and interoperable computerised customs systems, which will help facilitate commercial practices.

intervention.name: Nuno MELO
intervention.p: Europe’s economic competitiveness is of crucial importance, specifically in terms of revitalising the internal market. In this context, customs play a fundamental role in enhancing competitiveness. Simplification of existing legislation and encouragement of computerised systems, making customs modern and dynamic, are essential for encouraging economic growth. Moving further forward, the creation of a European Customs Union dealing with customs issues will facilitate cooperation between the players involved, guaranteeing safety and responsibility in terms of the flow of transparent information.

intervention.name: Louis MICHEL
intervention.p_group: Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe
intervention.p: An efficient Customs Union is one of the cornerstones of the European integration process and a basis for the free movement of goods, economic development and growth in the internal market. In order to play its role to the full extent, customs has to be modern, cooperative, responsive and efficient. To this end, Member States must allocate sufficient resources to customs, in particular to develop IT systems, so as to ensure its much-needed modernisation. An effective customs policy also plays a key role in protecting intellectual property rights, combating the illegal entry of counterfeit goods and products into the single market, and therefore enhances safety and security for European consumers. Modernising customs procedures should not, however, create unnecessary burdens, especially on SMEs. Consistency in the management of the European Union’s external borders is essential. We must ensure greater harmonisation of customs control systems and sanctions.

intervention.name: Alexander MIRSKY
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: Since I believe that an EU modernised system of customs should aim at enhancing EU competitiveness while aiming at improving product safety, market surveillance, guaranteeing protection for EU consumers as well as the EU’s financial interest, I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Andreas MÖLZER
intervention.p: The removal of the EU’s internal borders has given the customs service a completely new significance, which is why it would seem high time to modernise it. Ensuring the security of the international supply chain has gained greater importance, while the original function of customs, namely, the levying of excise duties, is almost solely relevant at external borders. The fact is that the requisite IT measures are unable to cope with current requirements, leading to a delay in the application of the Modernised Customs Code. I voted against the report because I do not agree with the rapporteur’s recommendation that the 27 customs authorities should be brought together to form a single organisation.

intervention.name: Alfredo PALLONE
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of Mr Salvini’s report because modernising customs is in line with the legislative simplification that we are addressing in all areas. Simplifying customs procedures improves the efficiency of controls and the application of standards. Furthermore, harmonisation between the EU’s 27 customs administrations – which ought to function as if they were a single entity in order to improve information transparency and speed up its transmission – helps controls by contributing to the fight against fraud. Cooperation between the various stakeholders and institutions in the customs sector and uniform treatment across the European Union are essential for ensuring that customs carry out their role as well as possible.

intervention.name: Maria do Céu PATRÃO NEVES
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: I voted in favour of this resolution, which emphasises the importance of ensuring that legitimate customs checks carried out by third countries are not used illegitimately, in some circumstances, to create new de facto tariff barriers to goods originating in the European Union. Particularly in the current economic climate, we must fight against any such potential tariff barriers

intervention.name: Paulo RANGEL
intervention.p: By introducing a control system for products entering the common market, customs ensure the security of goods moving within the European area but also form barriers to the free movement of goods. Hence, legislation must swing between two opposing preoccupations: defending Europe’s competitiveness without infringing central tenets of EU action.

The Modernised Customs Code, introduced in 2008, aimed to meet this objective by introducing control methods marked by simpler procedures. However, its potential has still not been fully realised as certain other actions are also needed before it can be properly implemented. This is an area that requires maximum cooperation between the various Member States so as to ensure uniform implementation of Union law. These are the points which I saw addressed in the resolution awaiting approval by the European Parliament, and that is why I voted in favour.

intervention.name: Raül ROMEVA i RUEDA
intervention.p_group: Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance - Vice
intervention.p: In favour. European economic competitiveness is of paramount importance especially with a view to revitalising the internal market. Customs has a significant role to play in improving and influencing competitiveness, as simplification of customs legislation and promotion of electronic customs stimulate economic growth. In order to play its role to the full extent, customs has to be modern, cooperative, responsive and active. Simultaneously, customs plays an essential role in guaranteeing safety and security efficiently, protecting the intellectual property rights, contributing to the fight against fraud. The rapporteur strongly believes that the cooperation among various stakeholders and institutions in the area of customs (traders, customs authorities, other governmental agencies, the Commission and the European Parliament) is essential to guarantee that customs fulfil its mission as described above; in particular, the rapporteur strongly supports timely and transparent flow of information among all the parties involved.

intervention.name: Licia RONZULLI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: European economic competitiveness is of paramount importance, especially with a view to revitalising the internal market. Customs has a significant role to play in improving and influencing competitiveness, as simplification of customs legislation and the promotion of electronic customs stimulate economic growth. Customs must be modern if they are to play their full role. The report that has been adopted today highlights how cooperation between the various stakeholders and institutions is essential for ensuring that customs fulfil their purpose. We need to ensure cooperation among customs authorities, as well as between customs authorities and traders, and customs authorities and other governmental authorities. Coordinated border management, the single window principle, the one-stop shop concept and centralised customs clearance must all be essential components of future reform.

intervention.name: Oreste ROSSI
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I support the own-initiative report on postponing the implementation of the regulation on the Modernised Customs Code until 2016, though it was supposed to come into force in 2013. The main reasons for this relate to the lack of software needed to tie together the customs activities of the Member States and, above all, businesses in the sector that trade with third countries. This would have led to the risk of illegal imports of counterfeit or unsafe goods to the EU, or to delays and setbacks, which would have wreaked significant economic damage on our industries.

intervention.name: Tokia SAÏFI
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: This report provides an opportunity to underline the crucial and multifaceted role of the customs authorities. They are, in fact, responsible for the day-to-day safety of goods and persons; they have to ensure compliance with intellectual property rights, health regulations, immigration rules, product safety, and so on. Moreover, they do all this without impeding freedom of movement within the European Union. I must, however, highlight one problem common to customs authorities in the Member States: the lack of resources. Let us be realistic: we cannot ask them to guard the fort and to deal with every single situation, while at the same time reducing their financial and human resources. This is why I would like to increase customs cooperation and funding, so as to support their efforts to switch to electronic procedures and streamline inspections. That is the price that we have to pay in order to ensure effective and satisfactory protection for our citizens and our businesses.

intervention.name: Nikolaos SALAVRAKOS
intervention.p_group: Europe of freedom and democracy Group
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report by Matteo Salvini because it quite rightly identifies the need to modernise customs in Europe. Competitiveness in the economic sector in Europe is vitally important, especially if we are to revive the internal market. The customs sector plays an important role in improving and influencing competitiveness and simplifying customs legislation and promoting e-customs will stimulate the economy.

intervention.name: Matteo SALVINI
intervention.p: I would like to explain my vote in favour of the report on the modernisation of customs, because this is an important and much-needed text that enables the Commission to postpone the entry into force of a regulation adopted in 2008 and slated for implementation in 2013. Our delegation would have preferred to purge the text of references to the non-preferential origin principle, which we do not support, has nothing to do with the text of the report, and which we will fight if it is put forward again during the debate on the legislative proposal.

intervention.name: Debora SERRACCHIANI
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted in favour of the report on modernising customs because I think we need to simplify customs legislation in order to improve and influence competitiveness. Customs play an essential role in ensuring efficient safety checks and contributing, above all, to the fight against fraud. This, however, requires efficient IT systems so as to ensure product safety and to block the sale of less safe products. However, I did vote against the parts referring to non-preferential origin of goods, not because I do not support the principle, but because I think the reference to the definition of the product origin should not be in this report, which aims to establish criteria for improving customs competitiveness.

intervention.name: Sergio Paolo Francesco SILVESTRIS
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: An efficient Customs Union is one of the essential cornerstones of the European integration process and a basis for the free movement of goods, economic development and growth in the internal market. The EU’s Modernised Customs Code, which was adopted in 2008, is highly ambitious in terms of deadlines, but the new proposal must aim at genuinely improving the current situation, bringing clear added value for EU operators and small and medium-sized enterprises in particular. We need to step up the fight against breaches of customs regulations and against the threats posed by smuggling, organised crime, corruption, terrorism and other criminal acts. These goals can be reached by paying particular attention to implementing the recommendations of the World Customs Organisation on risk management, the protection and security of legal trade, developing partnerships with business in the area of customs automation, and on the fight against corruption.

intervention.name: Nuno TEIXEIRA
intervention.p_group: Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats)
intervention.p: The competitiveness of the European Union is of huge importance, especially at the present moment, with the prospect of revitalising the European single market. Customs systems have a significant part to play in this, namely by simplifying customs legislation and upgrading its electronic and digital component. However, if the customs procedures of the Member States are indeed to contribute to improving European competitiveness, then modernisation and greater cooperation, plus action and responsibility, must go hand in hand with guarantees of security and efficiency.

intervention.name: Silvia-Adriana ȚICĂU
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: I voted for the report on the modernisation of customs as this service has a crucial role in guaranteeing safety and security, protecting consumers and the environment, ensuring complete revenue collection, strengthening the fight against fraud and corruption, and ensuring respect for intellectual property rights. A practical, simple and effective customs system is vital for facilitating the movement of goods and trade on the internal market, especially for SMEs, An effective customs policy plays a key role in ensuring the safety and security of European consumers. The customs service today faces increasing volumes of import, export and transit transactions, and e-customs is one of the main aspects for modernising and simplifying the customs service. I think that modernising the EU’s customs strategy and customs instruments should be a high political priority, supported by an ample budget. We welcome the Commission’s initiative to promote the adoption of e-invoicing at EU level, a measure which will help simplify transactions and reduce tax fraud. We call on the Commission to submit to the European Parliament by June 2012 a report on the current status of compliance by Member States with EU customs legislation, including an action plan to rectify any shortcomings identified.

intervention.name: Derek VAUGHAN
intervention.p_group: Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament
intervention.p: This resolution calls on Member States to take action to modernise customs procedures across the EU. In particular, this report calls for serious action to be taken to combat illegal imports. Greater cooperation between customs authorities in all Member States will combat the trade in illegal and counterfeit goods, and ensure greater product safety and protection of intellectual property rights across the EU. A seamless and harmonised application of EU customs legislation throughout the EU will enhance the competitiveness of EU firms, but MEPs pointed out that customs controls should primarily target high-risk consignments to reduce the burden and cost on importers and customs authorities.

intervention.name: Angelika WERTHMANN
intervention.p: The revision of the 2008 Customs Code is intended, above all, to simplify customs procedures. Modern customs practices ensure legal certainty and protect intellectual property, while also providing mechanisms to combat fraud and to ensure the security of international supply chains. The implementing provisions for the Modernised Customs Code have not yet come into force and the rapporteur recommends extending the deadline in order to take account of IT developments. I voted in favour.
